title: Avalanche in Sikkim, India kills seven, injures twelve
content:
On Tuesday morning, an avalanche near Nathu La pass in Sikkim, India, tragically claimed the lives of at least seven tourists and injured at least twelve others, with reports indicating that eight individuals remain in critical condition. 

The cause of the avalanche has yet to be determined.

By Wednesday, rescue teams, including members of the Sikkim Police, had successfully located 20 survivors, although News18 estimates the number could be as high as 22. 

Rescue operations were temporarily halted on Tuesday evening but resumed on Wednesday morning. A police administrator stated, “Rescue operations have resumed this morning because we want to ensure no one has been left behind. We will thoroughly search the area before concluding our efforts.”

The avalanche occurred approximately 56 kilometers from the state capital, Gangtok. Known as the "Land of Mystic Splendour," Nathu La attracts thousands of tourists each year and is also frequented by Hindu pilgrims undertaking a significant religious journey.

A 2018 study published in *Nature Communications* found that climate change has increased the likelihood and severity of avalanches in the Western Himalayas.
question:
What was the reported outcome of the avalanche near Nathu La pass in Sikkim, India?  
A) It caused significant property damage but no fatalities.  
B) It resulted in at least seven fatalities and injured at least twelve others.  
C) It left all tourists unharmed.  
D) It was caused by an earthquake.

title: Troops freed by Mali return to Ivory Coast
content:
On Saturday, 46 Ivorian troops returned to Abidjan after being released from six months of detention in Mali on charges of mercenarism. Their release came just a day after they were pardoned by Mali's military leader. The soldiers had been held since July on allegations of "undermining state security" in the Malian capital, igniting tensions between the two neighboring countries. The Ivorian government maintains that the troops were deployed in Mali as part of a UN mission aimed at combating militant Islamists.

The pardon followed diplomatic efforts that included a visit from an Ivorian delegation to Mali and mediation by Togolese President Faure Gnassingbé, who was thanked by the Malian government for his role in resolving the matter.

Since a military coup in August 2020 that ousted the elected president, Mali's relations with other West African nations have become increasingly strained. The Ivory Coast has been a vocal opponent of the coup.

The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), which includes the Ivory Coast as a member, had threatened to impose new sanctions starting January 1 if the troops were not released. Previously, ECOWAS had enacted sanctions against Mali after military leader Assimi Goïta postponed elections originally scheduled for February 2021 by four years. These sanctions were lifted in July 2022 when Malian authorities proposed a two-year transition to democracy.

Mali's relations with Western powers have also soured as the country has sought closer ties with Russia to combat the militant threat in the region. France officially concluded its military operation against insurgents in Mali in November 2022, and the UK has also announced the withdrawal of its troops from the country.
question:
What was the reason for the detention of the 46 Ivorian troops in Mali?

A) Illegal immigration  
B) Human trafficking  
C) Undermining state security  
D) Drug smuggling

title: UN humanitarian chief Martin Griffiths urges guarantees of safe passage for aid amid Sudan conflict
content:
**UN Urges Safe Passage for Humanitarian Aid Amid Sudan Conflicts**

On Wednesday, the United Nations' top humanitarian aid official, Martin Griffiths, called on warring factions in Sudan to make a public commitment to ensure the safe passage of humanitarian aid. He reported that the World Food Programme (WFP) informed him that six of its trucks were looted while en route to Darfur, despite assurances from the forces that their operations would not be disrupted.

Griffiths is currently in Sudan to assess how to deliver aid to millions affected by ongoing clashes between the Sudanese Armed Forces and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitary group. During a video call with the media, he emphasized the need for agreements to facilitate the movement of staff and supplies. "We will require a public, high-level agreement that can be relied upon at the local level," he stated.

He mentioned that he had spoken to General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, the head of the Army, and General Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, the RSF leader, urging them to establish safe zones for aid delivery. "Face-to-face discussions are essential so that we can create a moment of accountability," Griffiths said.

Highlighting the urgency of the situation, he added, "We are not asking for the impossible; we simply want the unimpeded movement of humanitarian supplies and personnel. This is a standard practice in humanitarian efforts even in the absence of ceasefires."

On Twitter, Griffiths called for ensuring safe passage for civilians fleeing conflict zones and for respect towards humanitarian workers and their resources.

Meanwhile, Volker Perthes, the UN Special Representative for Sudan, reported in an interview with Sky News that all warehouses belonging to the WFP, the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR), and various other agencies in Darfur had been looted. "Humanitarian vehicles, including those of my mission, were targeted, and many offices in towns across Darfur were also ransacked," he stated. Perthes noted that the WFP lost approximately 4,000 metric tons of humanitarian goods due to the looting, severely hindering aid distribution.

Perthes also recounted distressing incidents involving staff members being threatened at gunpoint and forced out of their homes by armed fighters. He revealed that there was at least one attempted sexual assault on a female staff member and reported damages from stray bullets and shells to staff housing.

Recent statistics indicated that 70% of the 330,000 internally displaced persons in Sudan are from Darfur.

In a related development, the South Sudanese Foreign Ministry announced on Tuesday that the Army and the RSF had agreed "in principle" to a seven-day truce from May 4 to May 11. The Sudanese Army expressed support for extending an ongoing ceasefire and engaging with leaders from South Sudan, Kenya, and Djibouti, as suggested by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD).

Despite agreeing to several ceasefires, actual compliance has not been observed. IGAD official Ismail Wais noted, "Although the two generals accept ceasefire agreements, fighting and shelling persist." He expressed concern that continued hostilities exacerbate the political, security, and humanitarian crises in the region.

Perthes shared insights about ongoing discussions, stating the goal is to convene both generals in a manner that allows them to face each other and agree on the details of a ceasefire beyond mere declarations.

The ongoing conflict stems from a power struggle that began after the Sudanese Army overthrew President Omar al-Bashir in 2019 following widespread protests against his three-decade rule. After a coup in 2021, General al-Burhan, with RSF leader Dagalo as his deputy, assumed control of a military council governing Sudan. Tensions escalated over the integration of the RSF into the national army, leading to violent confrontations that erupted on April 15. The RSF, which has a strength of approximately 100,000 fighters, is a successor to the Janjaweed militia used during Darfur's ethnic conflicts under al-Bashir's regime.
question:
What did the UN's top humanitarian aid official, Griffiths, urge warring factions in Sudan to commit to for humanitarian aid?

A) A permanent ceasefire  
B) Free access for foreign military  
C) Safe passage for humanitarian aid  
D) A complete withdrawal of troops

title: British boxer Amir Khan receives ban for doping
content:
On Tuesday, former world champion boxer and Olympic silver medalist Amir Khan received a two-year doping ban from the UK Anti-Doping (UKAD) organization. 

The suspension, retroactively effective from April 2022, stems from Khan's positive test for a substance that promotes muscle growth after his sixth-round technical loss to Kell Brook in February. Khan announced his retirement just three months following the fight. Despite stepping away from the sport, he has been issued this ban, which is set to expire in April 2024. 

Khan acknowledged that he violated anti-doping rules and does not intend to appeal the decision. However, he described the ban as "strange and funny," considering he has no plans for a return to boxing. While he accepted responsibility for the violation, Khan insisted that he did not intentionally consume the banned substance. An independent panel recognized his claims in January, but he was still handed the ban based on the principle of strict liability. 

"This case serves as a reminder that UKAD will diligently pursue anti-doping rule violations in order to protect clean sport," stated UK Anti-Doping chief executive Jane Rumble. "Strict liability means athletes are ultimately responsible for what they ingest and for the presence of any prohibited substances in their samples."
question:
What substance was the former world champion boxer Amir Khan found to have tested positive for, leading to his two-year doping ban?  
A) Stimulant  
B) Anabolic steroid  
C) Painkiller  
D) Performance-enhancing drug

title: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy meets Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen in California
content:
On Wednesday, Kevin McCarthy, the Speaker of the US House of Representatives, met with Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen in California. This marks a significant moment, as McCarthy is the highest-ranking American official to meet a Taiwanese leader on US soil since the US established official relations with China in 1979.

During a press conference following the meeting, McCarthy emphasized, "The friendship between the people of Taiwan and America is of profound importance to the free world. It is critical to uphold economic freedom, peace, and regional stability."

Representative [Name], a Republican who attended the meeting, shared a tweet containing an email from Li Xiang, a counsellor at the Chinese Embassy, expressing "China's deep concern and firm opposition to this possible move."

Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi praised the meeting in a statement for its leadership, bipartisan participation, and the historic significance of its venue.

In a press conference on Wednesday, [Spokesperson's Name], a spokesperson for [Title or Organization], noted that the meeting was "not official," adding that "she's not meeting with any [...] [executive] officials."

This meeting concluded Tsai's week-long trip to North and Central America, during which she engaged with various US Representatives, including House Minority Leader [Name], as well as Senators [Names].

China regards Taiwan as part of its territory and has recently reiterated its intention to assert control over the island, even by force if necessary, according to Politico.

The 1979 Taiwan Relations Act led to the establishment of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), a nongovernmental organization designed to maintain unofficial relations between Taiwan and the US after President Jimmy Carter recognized the People's Republic of China as "the sole legal government of China."
question:
Who became the highest American official to meet a Taiwanese head of state on American soil since 1979?  

A) Nancy Pelosi  
B) Kevin McCarthy  
C) Joe Biden  
D) Mark Kelly

title: Archbishop of Canterbury crowns King Charles III in the UK
content:
On Saturday, King Charles III was officially crowned as the sovereign of the United Kingdom in a grand ceremony held in London. His wife, Camilla, was also crowned during the event.

Charles ascended to the throne on September 8, following the passing of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II. While this coronation was largely symbolic as Charles had already become king, the government meticulously planned the event for several months.

The ceremony, presided over by Archbishop Welby, lasted approximately two hours and drew an audience of 2,300, including numerous foreign dignitaries and diplomats. The BBC noted that the event was shorter than the coronation of Elizabeth II, which took place 70 years earlier.

“I come not to be served, but to serve,” Charles stated at the outset of the ceremony. At 74 years old, he is the oldest individual to ascend to the British throne.

Archbishop Welby crowned Charles with the St. Edward's Crown, as soldiers lifted a screen and a choir performed traditional music—elements emblematic of British coronations for nearly 300 years.

While the ceremony followed Anglican traditions, it was notable for the inclusion of representatives from Buddhism, Hinduism, Judaism, and Islam for the first time. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak read from the Bible, and songs in various languages were incorporated into the proceedings.

Welby placed the crown on Charles’s head as he sat in the coronation chair, with the anointing oil applied beneath it. William, the heir to the throne, kissed his father's cheek and pledged his loyalty. Charles's second son, Harry, also attended, though he was without his spouse, Meghan.

Following the crowning, enthusiastic attendees shouted, "God save the King!" as celebrations rang out across the kingdom.

After the ceremony, Charles and Camilla made their way to Buckingham Palace in a horse-drawn carriage, escorted by soldiers, while thousands of onlookers lined the streets.

However, the event was not without controversy, as anti-monarchy groups, including Republic, gathered to advocate for the abolition of the monarchy. The Metropolitan Police reported 52 arrests related to the protests, having advised a "low tolerance" approach to any disruptions during the ceremony.

Human Rights Watch criticized the arrests, calling the reports of peaceful protesters being detained "incredibly alarming," and likened the situation to practices one would expect in Moscow rather than London.

In defense of the police actions, Commander stated, "Our duty is to do so in a proportionate manner in line with relevant legislation."
question:
Who presided over the coronation ceremony of King Charles III?  
A) Prime Minister Rishi Sunak  
B) The Archbishop of Canterbury  
C) Queen Elizabeth II  
D) A member of the royal family

title: First NASA TROPICS satellites launch to monitor tropical storms
content:
On Sunday at around 1:00 PM local time (01:00 UTC), a rocket successfully launched the first two of four NASA satellites as part of the Time-Resolved Observations of Precipitation Structure and Storm Intensity with a Constellation of Smallsats (TROPICS) program from New Zealand.

These CubeSats are designed to create a network in low-Earth orbit, enabling more frequent observations of precipitation, temperature, and humidity related to tropical cyclones than current weather satellites can provide.

A program executive at NASA noted, "TROPICS aims to enhance our scientific understanding by capturing microwave observations that allow us to analyze the inner structure of storms nearly every hour."

The data gathered by TROPICS will be shared with various organizations, including the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the National Hurricane Center (NHC).

The satellites are expected to commence observations ahead of the upcoming hurricane season. NASA highlighted that last year, three hurricanes that struck the U.S. caused over $100 billion in damages and resulted in more than 100 fatalities.

Rocket Lab secured the launch contract in November, following NASA's termination of a previous contract with Astra. This decision came after an Astra rocket experienced an ignition failure in June, which led to the destruction of two TROPICS satellites as the rocket's upper stage reentered the atmosphere.
question:
What is the primary objective of the TROPICS program launched by NASA?  

A) To expand human presence in low Earth orbit  
B) To collect more frequent observations of tropical cyclones' precipitation, temperature, and humidity  
C) To develop new rocket technology  
D) To map the Earth's surface in high detail

title: Labour becomes largest party in UK local government after 2023 English elections
content:
Labour has overtaken the Conservatives to become the largest party in UK local government as a result of the elections held on Thursday across England. This marks a significant shift, as Labour had been in the minority in local governance since 2002.

Elections were conducted for 230 local government authorities, the first time all these seats had been contested since 2019. According to reports from the BBC and Sky News, the Conservatives faced a loss of over 1,000 councillors; the Press Association noted that, accounting for those who had left the party between elections, the actual loss was estimated at 960 councillors. Labour gained 635 seats, while the Liberal Democrats flipped 416 seats and the Green Party secured 200.

The Conservatives gained control of two authorities but lost 45 overall, while Labour lost control of one authority yet managed to flip 19 others. The Green Party celebrated its best local election results ever, taking control of an English authority for the first time.

Voting was suspended in the Southampton ward following the death of the Conservative candidate on polling day, with the council pledging to hold a new poll within 35 working days.

Labour Party leader Sir Keir Starmer suggested that a resurgence in Scotland could lead to a majority for Labour in the next general election. Speaking to supporters in a newly won constituency, Starmer declared: "Make no mistake, we are on course for a Labour majority at the next general election."

In response, Conservative Prime Minister Rishi Sunak described the results as "disappointing," but asserted he did not see any significant shift of support towards Labour or excitement for its agenda.

A Labour spokesperson called the outcomes "a clear rejection of a prime minister who never had a mandate to begin with."

Local councils manage essential services such as state schools and highway maintenance. Upcoming council elections in Northern Ireland are set for May 18.

Sky News Election Analyst noted that if these results were mirrored in a general election, they would likely result in a hung parliament, with Labour as the largest party, followed by the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats in third place.

Liberal Democrats leader Sir Ed Davey remarked, "It's little wonder Rishi Sunak is running scared of a general election, because he knows we are set to take swathes of seats across the Conservative Party's former heartlands."
question:
What significant change occurred in UK local government after the recent elections held on Thursday? 

A) The Conservatives regained control of local councils  
B) Labour became the largest party in UK local government  
C) The Green Party won the majority of all authorities  
D) Liberal Democrats lost several council seats

title: Supporters of ex-President Bolsonaro storm Brazil's Congress, Supreme Court
content:
Supporters of far-right former President Jair Bolsonaro stormed key government buildings in Brazil's capital, Brasília, today, a week after the inauguration of leftist opponent Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. The mob surrounded the Congress and other government offices, mirroring scenes from past political upheaval.

Police have since regained control of the buildings and detained hundreds of participants in the chaos. Footage from national television and social media captured approximately 3,000 protesters, dressed in Brazil's national colors of green and yellow, as they marched from army headquarters to the government complex. They smashed windows, climbed onto rooftops, and breached security barriers, while police deployed tear gas ineffectively. Once inside the buildings, the rioters vandalized property, destroyed furniture, and set up barricades to impede security forces.

At the time of the unrest, neither house of Congress was in session, and President Lula was out of sight, though some staff members were reported to be at the presidential palace and awaiting aerial evacuation. Justice Minister Flávio Dino confirmed he was at the ministry’s headquarters during the events. Senate President Rodrigo Pacheco stated that he was in "permanent contact" with the Governor of the Federal District, who is managing the situation.

International leaders have condemned the violence and expressed solidarity with Lula. Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez offered "full support to President Lula and to the institutions freely and democratically chosen by the Brazilian people." Chilean President Gabriel Boric denounced the assault as a "cowardly and vile attack on democracy," while Colombian President Gustavo Petro described it as a manifestation of "fascism attempting a coup."

Lula won the presidency in a contentious election held on October 30, which many of Bolsonaro's supporters dispute, alleging electoral fraud despite the lack of evidence. One protester, identified as Lima, told Agence France-Presse: "We need to re-establish order after this fraudulent election." Bolsonaro himself had previously cast doubt on the legitimacy of the electronic voting system and failed to concede defeat.

On the eve of Lula's inauguration on January 1, Bolsonaro left Brazil and is currently residing in Florida. His supporters have consistently expressed their desire for military intervention, with previous protests involving attempts to storm police headquarters and acts of arson against vehicles.

Today's events have drawn comparisons to the January 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol by Trump supporters attempting to overturn Joe Biden’s election victory. The U.S. Ambassador to Brazil under Barack Obama, Thomas Shannon, noted in August that Bolsonaro and his team closely studied those events to understand why a sitting president was unable to alter election outcomes.
question:
What significant event occurred in Brasília, Brazil, a week after the inauguration of President Lula da Silva?

A) A peaceful protest in support of President Lula  
B) A far-right mob stormed government buildings  
C) A military coup successfully ousted President Lula  
D) A celebration of Lula’s election victory

title: 118th United States Congress convenes; House of Representatives adjourns without electing Speaker for first time in 100 years
content:
The United States Congress convened on Tuesday to begin its new session, with Vice President and President of the Senate Kamala Harris administering the oath of office to newly elected and reelected Senators shortly after noon EST (17:00 UTC).

The Republican-majority House of Representatives is currently engaged in a contentious election for Speaker.

In the initial ballot on Tuesday, all 212 House Democrats cast their votes for their leader, Representative Hakeem Jeffries, while 203 House Republicans supported their leader, Representative Kevin McCarthy. Nineteen Republicans opted for alternative candidates. As no nominee received the 218 votes required for a majority, the House faced an unprecedented situation, resulting in a second ballot – the first time this has occurred since 1923.

The second ballot yielded identical results for Jeffries and McCarthy, but the group of 19 Republicans opposed to McCarthy voted unanimously for Representative Jim Jordan, despite his earlier withdrawal from the race and endorsement of McCarthy.

A third ballot followed, revealing 212 votes for Jeffries, 202 for McCarthy, and 20 for Jordan. The House then adjourned at approximately 5:29 PM EST (22:29 UTC) and is scheduled to reconvene at noon EST (17:00 UTC) on Wednesday.

As of Thursday, the House has still not elected a Speaker, having conducted six ballots. Once the Speaker is determined, they will be responsible for swearing in the members-elect and guiding the House in establishing rules for the current session.

Meanwhile, in the Democratic-majority Senate, Harris swore in the most senior Senator, Washington State Democrat Patty Murray, as President pro tempore. Murray, the first woman to hold this position, is now third in the presidential line of succession. The Senate began adopting its rules on Tuesday afternoon.

Senators serve staggered six-year terms, meaning that during federal elections held every two years, roughly one-third of the 100 Senate seats are contested. Currently, there are 51 Democrats (which includes three independents who caucus with them) and 49 Republicans in the Senate. In contrast, Representatives serve two-year terms, resulting in all House seats being up for election during every federal election; the current composition of the House stands at 222 Republicans, 212 Democrats, and one vacancy.
question:
What significant event took place in the United States Congress on Tuesday regarding the House of Representatives?

A) The House elected a new Speaker for the first time since 1923  
B) All members of the House were sworn in by the Vice President  
C) The House held its first vote since the 2022 midterm elections  
D) The House was adjourned without electing a Speaker

title: Japanese military helicopter goes down at sea, 10 missing
content:
A Japanese military helicopter crashed off the coast of Miyako Island on Thursday, with all 10 individuals on board reported missing.

The helicopter, a variant of the Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk, belonged to the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force (JGSDF). Japanese radar lost contact with the aircraft approximately 10 minutes after its departure from Miyako Island, between Miyako Island and the nearby area.

Early Friday morning, search teams discovered a door, a rotor blade, and an unused lifeboat that matched the markings of the missing helicopter during their search efforts.

Defense Minister Yasuhide Nakayama stated, "We will do everything possible to rescue the 10 individuals who are still missing while we continue to gather information about the situation."

Onboard the helicopter were two pilots, two mechanics, and six passengers, including Lieutenant General Yuichi Sakamoto, a senior JGSDF commander overseeing the region.

The JGSDF confirmed that the helicopter had passed a safety inspection in March.
question:
What was reported to have happened to the Japanese military helicopter off the coast of Miyako Island on Thursday?

A) It was successfully retrieved.  
B) All 10 aboard were reported missing.  
C) It underwent a safety inspection immediately before flying.  
D) It was attacked by enemy forces.

title: Maryland, US attorney general's office alleges historic child sexual abuse by Catholic Church officials
content:
The Office of the Attorney General of Maryland released a report on Wednesday detailing allegations of sexual abuse involving clergy members and others associated with the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore. The investigation, which began in 2018, identifies more than 600 child victims of abuse spanning from the 1940s to 2002.

The report identifies 156 alleged abusers, naming all but ten individuals due to redactions mandated by a Baltimore circuit court. It states, “Over 600 children are known to have been abused by the 156 individuals included in this report, but the actual number is likely much higher.” The report refrains from naming victims, instead referring to them as “victims” rather than “survivors” to underscore the criminal nature of the acts committed against them.

The findings accuse the Catholic Church's leadership of complicity, stating, “The duration and scope of the abuse committed by clergy could only occur due to a lack of accountability from Church leaders.” It emphasizes that the Archdiocese repeatedly ignored reports of abuse, failed to conduct thorough investigations, did not identify other potential victims, and often reassigned known abusers to positions with access to children. The report criticizes the Church’s focus on concealing abuse rather than protecting children.

Additionally, the report includes a list of individuals transferred to the Archdiocese of Baltimore who had been "credibly accused" of abuse in other jurisdictions.

During a press conference announcing the report, Attorney General Anthony Brown declared, “Today marks a day of reckoning and accountability in Maryland.” He stated that the stories of abuse reveal common patterns of power dynamics, noting how abusive priests and Church leadership exerted control over survivors and their families.

In response to the findings, Archbishop William Lori issued a statement apologizing to survivors and pledging his support for their healing. He acknowledged the impact of their courageous testimonies and committed to measures aimed at preventing future abuse.

Jean Hargadon Wehner, who alleged she was raped multiple times in the 1970s, expressed her disappointment with the Church’s past actions, reflecting on her frustration that officials did not respond adequately to her reports in 1992. Her accused perpetrator, A. Joseph Maskell, a priest who was also her high school counselor, is claimed to have had at least 39 victims.

Kurt Rupprecht, another abuse survivor, emphasized the ongoing impact of his trauma, noting that his abuser was reassigned instead of being held accountable. “We’re here to speak the truth and will never stop,” he said. “This is our life sentence.”

On the same day, Maryland lawmakers passed a bill aimed at eliminating the statute of limitations on sex crimes against children. The legislation, which had already received approval from the Maryland Senate in March, will become law once signed by Governor Wes Moore, who has expressed support for the bill. Currently, Maryland law permits victims to pursue legal action only until they turn 38 years old.
question:
What was the main finding of the Maryland Attorney General's report regarding sexual abuse in the Archdiocese of Baltimore?  

A) Over 600 children were allegedly abused by clergy members and others.  
B) All clergy accused of abuse were convicted in court.  
C) The report found no evidence of abuse in the Archdiocese.  
D) The report named all perpetrators without redactions.

title: US House of Representatives rejects resolution to order troop withdrawal from Syria
content:
On Wednesday, the US House of Representatives voted 321-103 against a resolution that sought to mandate the withdrawal of approximately 900 American troops currently stationed in Syria. 

The resolution was introduced by Republican Representative Matt Gaetz on February 21. Gaetz argued, "I do not believe that what stands between a caliphate and its absence are the 900 Americans who have been sent to this hellscape without a clear definition of victory." The Associated Press reported that a US operation in Syria just four days prior had resulted in the injury of four servicemembers while also eliminating a senior leader of the Islamic State.

On his congressional website, Gaetz emphasized that "Congress has never authorized kinetic participation of U.S. Armed Forces in Syria."

In contrast, Republican Representative and chair of the relevant committee warned that withdrawing US forces could rekindle the Islamic State’s strength. He stated, "The withdrawal of this legal, authorized US troop deployment must be contingent on the total defeat of ISIS."

Meanwhile, the top Democrat on the Foreign Affairs Committee cautioned that the measure would end the US mission prematurely at a pivotal moment for ongoing operations against the Islamic State. However, he expressed concern over an indefinite military presence in Syria.

Since September 2014, the US has conducted military operations in Syria against the Islamic State as part of a broader strategy that has been supported by multiple presidents under the 2001 Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF) and the 2002 AUMF.

The 2001 AUMF, which has been employed longer than any other AUMF in US history, was initially passed to authorize military action in response to the September 11 attacks. The 2002 AUMF was used to authorize the Iraq War.

Efforts in Congress to establish a new authorization for anti-Islamic State operations began in late 2014, as noted in a report.

On June 17, 2021, the House passed a bill aimed at repealing the 2002 AUMF. Representative Gregory Meeks remarked at the time that such repeal was crucial, given the executive branch's history of broadly interpreting the 2002 AUMF’s legal scope. However, the bill did not advance in the Senate.

On Wednesday, a Senate committee voted 13-8 in favor of repealing both the 2002 AUMF and a separate 1991 AUMF, setting the stage for a vote by the full Senate.
question:
What was the vote tally by the US House of Representatives on the resolution to require the withdrawal of approximately 900 US troops stationed in Syria?  

A) 321–103  
B) 250–175  
C) 200–218  
D) 400–30

title: Waymo announces expansion of autonomous taxi coverage in Arizona, San Francisco
content:
On May 4, Waymo, the US-based autonomous vehicle company, announced on its blog that its Waymo One service is set to nearly double its coverage in the Phoenix, Arizona area. This expansion includes a new stop that allows up to four passengers to ride in a robotaxi. The company will also extend its services to cover the entire city of San Francisco, California.

Chief Product Officer Saswat Panigrahi expressed optimism to the press: "We are feeling tremendous wind at our backs."

Currently, Waymo is providing 10,000 fully autonomous rides to the public each week, a number Panigrahi anticipates will grow to 100,000 by next summer. He clarified that this figure pertains solely to external riders and does not include trips taken by the company's own employees.

Panigrahi described the Phoenix area as the "largest contiguous AV area in the world." Waymo plans to extend its service to a 180-square mile (466 square kilometer) region that includes the resort town of Cave Creek, which will connect with its existing noncontiguous coverage areas of Phoenix and nearby communities such as Scottsdale, Tempe, Chandler, and Gilbert.

In San Francisco, rides will be offered free of charge around the clock, except in certain neighborhoods in the northeast, where only staff and select volunteer testers will be allowed. Waymo has asked for permission from local authorities to start charging for rides in San Francisco. If approved, this would make San Francisco the first city where two companies operate robotaxi services, as General Motors-owned Cruise has been charging for rides in parts of the city since June, particularly during nighttime.

However, Waymo One vehicles have faced challenges in San Francisco, including issues related to fog and the city's complex terrain. Previous incidents reported by the Associated Press include various robotaxis coming to a sudden stop in traffic—one situation involving five vehicles halting abruptly in foggy conditions—along with obstruction of emergency services and rear-end collisions with buses.

In response to these incidents, local regulators have criticized Waymo's expansion efforts in a letter to the Commission, labeling it as "unreasonable."

Panigrahi defended the initiative, stating: "As we deploy fully autonomous vehicles, we are committed to learning from our experiences, with safety as our top priority." He characterized Waymo One as "continuously improving."

The Phoenix Street Transportation Department declined to comment on safety measures for the robotaxis, explaining that it is not the regulating agency for autonomous vehicles.

Waymo, based in Mountain View, California, is a subsidiary of Alphabet Inc. and began as Google's secret autonomous vehicle project over a decade ago. It started testing in Phoenix in 2017 and commenced paid rides in late 2020 across an area of approximately 60 square miles (155 square kilometers).
question:
What is the expected weekly number of fully autonomous trips with public riders that Waymo aims to reach by next summer?  

A) 10,000  
B) 50,000  
C) 100,000  
D) 200,000

title: Powerful earthquake rocks Vanuatu archipelago
content:
An earthquake with a magnitude of 7.0 struck the Oceanian nation of Vanuatu at 11:30 PM on Saturday (10:30 UTC on Sunday). There have been no reports of casualties following the incident.

The United States Geological Survey issued a tsunami warning for "waves reaching 0.3 to one meter [3.9 feet] above the level" along the coasts of Vanuatu, New Caledonia, and the Solomon Islands. However, the warning was quickly lifted as no tsunami materialized.

In response to the quake, the French Embassy in Vanuatu urged residents to remain vigilant and prepared for potential aftershocks, posting a statement on their Facebook page.

Kayson Pore, a 22-year-old college student living on Vanuatu's largest island, recounted the harrowing experience to Agence France-Presse. "We were right on the sea, looking for crabs on the coast when we felt a very huge quake. We ran for our lives and then dashed to our homes… people were moving to higher ground to evade a possible tsunami."

Some residents took to social media to report minor damage. Pore mentioned that while the quake knocked over and shattered cups in his kitchen, he did not observe serious damage to homes in his town of 1,000 residents.

The New Zealand National Emergency Management Agency indicated that they did not anticipate any tsunami-related impacts on their coast.

The Vanuatu islands sit along the convergent boundary of the Indo-Australian and Pacific tectonic plates, an area known for frequent seismic activity.

In November, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake also rattled the Solomon Islands, but it resulted in no significant casualties or destruction. In contrast, a 2018 magnitude 7.5 earthquake on Indonesia's Sulawesi island claimed the lives of 4,300 people or left them missing.

According to last year's World Risk Report, which assesses the disaster risk of 193 countries, Vanuatu ranked 49th on its list.

content:

During the sentencing, Justice Richard Button characterized the murder as "spontaneous and not premeditated," while also acknowledging it as a "grave example of an extremely serious offence." He emphasized that while there was an intention to inflict serious harm, it existed only for a fleeting moment, preventing a conclusion of intent to kill.

Justice Button expressed concern over the violent nature of the act, stating, "The life of a fellow human being was violently extinguished in a place where he was entitled to feel safe. His final moments were short but terrifying, and he surely suffered immensely." He described the incident as a "deeply self-centered imposition of violence" on another person.

The judge also reflected on Musa's troubled childhood, describing it as "grossly deprived and traumatic." He noted that she was born in Sudan, grew up in poverty, and experienced significant hardships, including witnessing violence while fleeing conflict. Musa arrived in Australia as a refugee in 2004, grappling with post-traumatic stress disorder and other mental health challenges.

Justice Button acknowledged Musa's prior good character, highlighting her consistent employment and dedication to her four children and elderly mother, as well as her abstinence from drugs and alcohol. 

He remarked, "This case is a tragedy from many perspectives: from the viewpoint of the deceased and his loved ones, as well as from the perspective of the offender, her family, and society." He noted that the violence resulted from a moment of emotional turmoil, stating that the deceased was killed simply because he exercised his autonomy in personal matters.

On that day, Musa believed her boyfriend, 31-year-old Payman "Paul" Thagipur, was financially abusing her and felt isolated from him. After failing to reach him via text and searching for him at local cafes, she drove to his apartment in Wentworth Point.

title: Jury finds former US President Trump liable in defamation, sexual abuse case
content:
After less than three hours of deliberation, a federal jury in Manhattan found former US President Donald Trump liable for sexual abuse and defamation against plaintiff E. Jean Carroll. The jury, composed of six men and three women, awarded Carroll $5 million—approximately $2 million for sexual abuse and $3 million for defamation. 

The jury found Trump not liable for rape.

In response to the verdict, Trump expressed his outrage on his social media platform, calling it "A DISGRACE" and announced plans to appeal during an interview with Fox News Digital.

While visiting his properties in Scotland and Ireland, Trump indicated he would attend the trial's final stages but ultimately did not take the judge's offer to reopen the case and testify by May 7.

In a previously recorded video, Trump claimed he had "absolutely no idea who this woman [Carroll] is" and insisted she was "not my type." He also confused her with his second wife, Marla Maples, when presented with a photo featuring both women.

Trump has previously made controversial comments about women, asserting that as a "star," he could grab them by their genitals, stating, "Unfortunately or fortunately."

Carroll, a former advice columnist, testified over the course of three days. When questioned by defense attorney Joe Tacopina about why she did not scream during the alleged assault, Carroll replied, "One of the reasons women don't come forward is because they're always asked, 'Why didn't you scream?' Some women scream. Some women don't. It keeps women silent."

Tacopina also questioned why Carroll did not file a police report after the incident in the spring of 1996, to which she responded that she felt too "ashamed." She explained, "I was born in 1943. I'm a member of the silent generation. Women like me were taught to keep our chins up and not complain. I would never call the police about something I am ashamed of."

Two friends testified that Carroll informed them about the alleged assault shortly after it occurred. Carroll stated that following the attack, she was unable to smile at or engage with men she found attractive.

"I was never going to talk about what Donald Trump did," Carroll said, referring to her decision to publish a memoir in 2019 that included accusations against him, which she described as an encouragement to come forward.

Since the jury’s decision has been made, criminal charges against Trump are now barred due to the expiration of the statute of limitations. Carroll's lawsuit was filed under the 2022 Adult Survivors Act, which provided New Yorkers a year to file lawsuits against individuals accused of sex crimes.

What was the amount awarded to Carroll by the jury for sexual abuse and defamation against Donald Trump?

B) US$3 million

title: Australian broadcaster projects Liberal win in Ryde district, New South Wales, two weeks after state election

Labor secured 45 seats in the election, falling short of the 47 needed for a majority, which The Guardian anticipates will prompt newly elected Premier Chris Minns to engage in negotiations with the crossbenchers, consisting of nine independents and three from other parties.

In the 2019 election, Liberal candidate Victor Dominello won Ryde by an 18% margin, although that race noted a 2.6% swing in favor of Labor. Dominello, who has represented Ryde since 2008, retired prior to the recent election, and Lane has referred to him as "a close friend and mentor."

title: New study analyzes the varying levels of protection offered by COVID-19 vaccines
content:
A study conducted by researchers at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) has found that COVID-19 vaccines provide varying levels of protection in the six months following vaccination. The findings were published in a journal on Tuesday.

The BOOST study (Building Optimal Antibodies Study) included 498 volunteers, aged 18 to 88, who were assessed for COVID-19 neutralizing antibody levels after receiving the Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines.

One month post-vaccination, participants who received the Pfizer vaccine exhibited an antibody response that was 21 times greater than that of the Johnson & Johnson recipients. Additionally, those who received the Moderna vaccine displayed an antibody response that was 51 times higher than the Johnson & Johnson group. However, six months later, the antibody levels in the Johnson & Johnson group surpassed those of the Pfizer group and were comparable to those in the Moderna group.

Dr. Aric Prather from the UCSF Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences and the Weill Institute for Neurosciences emphasized this observation, stating, "While the mechanism for this increase is unknown, smaller studies have suggested a similar trend, which leads us to believe there are significant phenomena at play beyond our specific sample."

Although all three vaccines demonstrated effectiveness, the study also identified factors that may diminish vaccine efficacy. Male participants exhibited a 30% lower vaccine response compared to females, while smokers showed a stark reduction, with antibody levels measuring 240% lower than those of non-smokers. "Almost all of [the smokers] were unable to mount a strong antibody response," noted Dr. Elissa Epel, the study's senior author and vice chair of the UCSF Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences.

title: Russian authorities charge US reporter Evan Gershkovich with espionage
content:
On Friday, Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) formally charged journalist Evan Gershkovich, a U.S. citizen working for The Wall Street Journal, with espionage.

Gershkovich, 31, has "categorically denied" the allegations, asserting that he was engaged solely in journalistic reporting, according to sources.

U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, a Democrat, and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Republican, issued a joint statement on Friday emphasizing, "Let there be no mistake: journalism is not a crime. We demand the baseless, fabricated charges against Mr. Gershkovich be dropped and that he be immediately released. We reiterate our condemnation of the Russian government's ongoing attempts to intimidate, repress, and punish independent journalists and civil society voices."

The FSB arrested Gershkovich in the Ural Federal District on March 30, accusing him of "acting at the behest of the American side" and collecting state secrets related to Russian military-industrial activities. This marks the first instance of a U.S. journalist being charged with espionage by Russia since the Cold War.

The Wall Street Journal has called for the immediate release of its "trusted and dedicated reporter," describing his detention as "a vicious affront to a free press that should spur outrage among all free people and governments around the world."

On April 3, a national security spokesperson stated, "We will do everything we can to get Evan home… I don't have specific details about what it would take to negotiate with the Russians for his release."

The following day, White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre reaffirmed, "Evan is not a spy; Evan has never been a spy. This is a case that is a priority for the president."

Gershkovich met with his attorneys for the first time on April 4. As of April 5, he was being held at Lefortovo Prison in eastern Moscow. According to reports, Lefortovo is notorious for isolating prisoners and was originally built for the military in 1881, later serving the Soviet Union's KGB.
question:
What were US Senate leaders Schumer and McConnell's statements regarding the charges against journalist Evan Gershkovich? 

A) They supported the charges and called for an investigation.

D) They stated that journalism is a crime in certain circumstances.

title: President Tsai says Chinese military drills in Taiwan Strait create instability in region
content:
Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen issued a statement on April 11, accusing China of fostering instability in the region through its recent three-day military drills.

According to the Associated Press, the maneuvers were conducted in response to Tsai's recent visit to the United States, where she met with House Speaker Kevin McCarthy. This meeting marked the highest-level official engagement between a US politician and a Taiwanese president on US soil.

In her statement, Tsai emphasized her role as the representative of Taiwan on the global stage, stating, "As president, I represent our country in the world, whether visiting allied nations or transiting through the U.S. and engaging with our international friends. This has been the practice for years, and it reflects the shared aspirations of the Taiwanese people." She further asserted, "China has exploited this situation as a pretext to initiate military drills, thereby escalating tensions in the Taiwan Strait and the wider region. This behavior does not reflect the conduct of a responsible major power."

The military exercises, which began on Saturday, simulated attacks on Taiwan using carrier-based aircraft. The Japanese military reported observing 80 take-offs and landings from a Chinese aircraft carrier. In reaction, Japan's Air Self-Defense Force deployed fighter jets. CNN further reported that 35 aircraft from the People's Liberation Army (PLA) crossed the median line of the Taiwan Strait or entered Taiwan's air-defense identification zone.

The PLA claimed in a statement that the military operation "comprehensively tested the joint combat capabilities of its integrated forces under conditions akin to actual combat." It added that the forces remain "ready for combat at all times and will resolutely thwart any attempts towards 'Taiwan independence' or foreign interference."

Since formalizing unofficial relations with Taiwan in 1979, the United States has maintained a commitment to providing Taiwan with defensive arms.

title: India launches Small Satellite Launch Vehicle, deploying three low-earth orbit satellites
content:
On Friday, India's national space agency, the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), successfully conducted the second test flight of its Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV-D2), carrying three satellites into orbit.

The launch occurred at 9:18 AM IST (3:48 AM UTC) from the agency's first launchpad in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh. 

Following a 15-minute flight, all three satellites were successfully placed into a 450-kilometer (280-mile) orbit. The payloads included ISRO's Earth Observation Satellite-7 (EOS-07), which weighs 156.3 kilograms (344.6 lbs), the Janus-1 satellite from US-based Antaris, weighing 10.2 kilograms (22.5 lbs), and AzaadiSAT-2, developed by 750 female students and weighing 8.8 kilograms (19.4 lbs).

ISRO celebrated the success of the mission in a tweet, stating, "SSLV-D2/EOS-07 Mission is successfully accomplished. SSLV-D2 has placed EOS-07, Janus-1, and AzaadiSAT-2 into their intended orbits."

This successful flight comes after the SSLV's first test on August 7, which ended in failure when the vehicle, while successfully releasing its payload, placed them into an unstable orbit, failing to achieve the required velocity for a stable trajectory.

The SSLV is designed to cater to the commercial satellite market for payloads of up to 500 kilograms (1,100 lbs), providing a "launch-on-demand" service. Its designers aim to offer a low-cost, quick, and flexible access to space that accommodates a variety of satellite designs while requiring minimal launch infrastructure.
question:
At what time did ISRO conduct the second test flight of the SSLV-D2?  

A) 9:18 AM IST  
B) 3:48 AM UTC  
C) Both A and B  
D) 10:00 AM IST

title: Médecins Sans Frontières closes hospital amid rising violence in Haiti
content:
Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), also known as Doctors Without Borders, announced on Wednesday the temporary closure of their hospital in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, due to escalating gang violence that has made it impossible to ensure the safety of patients and staff.

In recent weeks, heavily armed gangs have expanded their control into parts of Port-au-Prince and surrounding areas, leading to stray bullets and violent confrontations occurring just meters from the hospital grounds. This surge in violence has forced local schools to close.

Vincent Harris, a medical adviser for MSF, stated, "Although our hospital has not been directly attacked, we find ourselves caught in the crossfire as it is situated on the frontline of this conflict. We understand that closing the hospital will significantly affect the people of Cité Soleil, but our team cannot operate under such unsafe conditions."

Despite the closure, Alexandre Marcou, MSF's field communication manager, stressed that the organization is not withdrawing from Haiti and is committed to intensifying their aid efforts when it is safe to do so.

The situation in Haiti has deteriorated since the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse in July 2021, with reports of murder, kidnapping, and sexual violence used by gangs to instill terror among residents. According to a United Nations report from November, gangs now control approximately 60% of the capital.

Haiti's acting prime minister, Ariel Henry, called last year for an international force to help re-establish order. While this appeal has garnered support from the UN and the United States, efforts to mobilize a international mission have stalled, as no country has yet agreed to lead a non-UN mission. 

Earlier this year, another MSF-supported hospital south of Port-au-Prince was forced to close after a patient was killed while leaving the emergency room.
question:
What action did Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) announce regarding their hospital in Haiti's capital? 

A) They expanded their services.
B) They temporarily closed the hospital.

title: China's Foreign Ministry sanctions US Representative Michael McCaul
content:
China imposed sanctions on the Republican chair of the United States House of Representatives on Thursday after he led a delegation of lawmakers to Taiwan last week, which Beijing characterized as "sending a serious wrong signal to Taiwan independence separatist forces." 

The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated these sanctions include freezing any assets the congressman may hold in China, prohibiting Chinese organizations and individuals from engaging with him, and denying him entry into China.

The Ministry's statement criticized McCaul, saying he has repeatedly interfered in China’s internal affairs and undermined its interests. His recent visit to Taiwan was described as a serious violation of the one-China principle and the trilateral relationship between China and the United States.

In response, McCaul issued a statement asserting, "Ironically, this baseless action serves U.S. interests by drawing more attention to our international partners and highlighting China's blatant aggression."

Historically, China has sanctioned foreign officials and entities that engage with Taiwan, including recent measures against those who facilitated a meeting between President Tsai and U.S. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Beijing has also targeted senior Taiwanese lawmakers for similar reasons.

Taiwan's government emphasized on Sunday that it has a "fundamental right" to pursue its own diplomatic relations.

A) Issued a formal apology  
B) Levied sanctions

title: UK Treasury considering plans for digital pound, economic secretary says
content:
During a session in the House of Commons on Tuesday, officials announced that the UK government is considering the introduction of a "digital pound" and plans to initiate public consultations regarding its features and regulatory framework in the upcoming weeks.

Speaking before the Treasury Committee, Economic Secretary Richard Griffith highlighted that the government is "a long way down the road" toward establishing a regulatory environment for the wholesale use of cryptocurrencies. He pointed out that these digital currencies could be designed to be less volatile by being pegged to traditional assets.

Griffith reasserted the UK's commitment to becoming a leading hub for cryptocurrency, but cautioned that creating regulations for a digital pound will be a lengthy process. He noted that the initial use of a digital pound is expected to be for settling wholesale financial transactions. However, he suggested that public policy considerations might indicate that a private, fiat-backed stablecoin could be utilized for these purposes before the digital pound is fully implemented.

Griffith emphasized the importance of addressing public policy issues correctly, stating, "I would rather be right than be first." He expressed hope that the regulatory framework, which will be the UK's first for crypto assets, would be incorporated into the Financial Services and Markets Bill currently under discussion in the House of Lords. He acknowledged that embracing this "potentially disruptive game-changing technology" could both challenge and enhance the UK's financial sector.

Globally, central banks are exploring digital currencies, with China piloting its digital yuan in major cities such as Beijing and Shanghai. Meanwhile, the European Union (EU) is set to publish draft legislation to establish and regulate a digital euro later this year. The European Central Bank is expected to conclude its two-year investigation into the digital euro by July, followed by a three-year implementation phase.

Amid growing scrutiny of consumer protection during the recent downturn in cryptocurrency values and the collapse of significant exchanges, the EU has put forth the world's first comprehensive regulatory framework for crypto markets, anticipated to take effect in 2024. Griffith indicated that the UK's regulations might be broader and encompass decentralized finance. He added that the public consultations on regulating crypto assets would be part of a "research and exploration" phase in collaboration with the government and the Bank of England, involving "at least" six discussions with industry stakeholders to ensure regulators and decision-makers are well-informed and uphold the UK's "strong financial reputation."
question:
What did UK officials announce regarding the digital pound in the House of Commons? 

A) The digital pound will launch by next month.  
B) The government is considering a digital pound and will hold public consultations on its attributes and regulation.  
C) The digital pound has been officially adopted by the government.  
D) There will be an immediate implementation of the digital pound.

title: G7 finance chiefs, central bankers commit to implementing plan to diversify supply chains by year's end
content:
Finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven (G7) concluded a three-day summit in Hiroshima, Japan, by issuing a communiqué on Saturday. They pledged to implement a strategy for diversifying supply chains by the end of the year, emphasizing the need for vigilance and flexibility in macroeconomic policies amid growing uncertainties regarding the global economic outlook.

The proposed plan aims to enhance the roles of low- and middle-income countries in energy-related supply chains through aid initiatives. The communiqué stated, "Diversification of supply chains can contribute to safeguarding energy security and help us maintain macroeconomic stability."

The communiqué also acknowledged the effectiveness of legislation established during the Great Recession in bolstering market resilience against instabilities in the banking system. Additionally, central bank leaders reaffirmed their commitment to addressing "elevated" inflation levels.

The group condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine and reiterated their intention to enforce sanctions, calling for an "immediate end" to the conflict, which they identified as one of the major uncertainties impacting the global economy.

Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki addressed the press, stating, "Through the pandemic, we learned that supply chains often depended on a limited number of countries or even a single country," highlighting the resulting shortages of crucial items such as medicines and computer chips. He stressed that economic security during the global transition to clean energy hinges on diversifying supply chains.

Suzuki also revealed that attendees discussed the potential risk of the United States defaulting on its debts during a dinner on Thursday, though he declined to provide further details. This issue, while not explicitly mentioned in the communiqué, was characterized by Reuters as a significant topic of discussion.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen had previously warned that a default could occur within weeks if lawmakers do not raise the nation's debt ceiling. UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt described such an outcome as "absolutely devastating."

The G7 leaders are scheduled to meet again starting Friday in Hiroshima.
question:
What was one key commitment made by the G7 finance ministers and central bankers regarding supply chains during their summit in Japan? 

A) To exclusively rely on high-income countries for energy supply chains  
B) To complete a plan for diversifying supply chains by the end of the year  
C) To implement new tariffs for imports from low-income countries  
D) To cease all economic sanctions on Russia

title: Loreen wins Eurovision for Sweden for second time
content:
On Saturday, Swedish singer Loreen, 39, celebrated her second victory at the Eurovision Song Contest held in Liverpool, United Kingdom. Loreen's performance earned a total of 583 points from both the public and expert juries.

Finland finished in second place with 526 points, followed closely by Israel in third with 362 points.

A total of 37 countries participated in this year's contest, with 26, including reigning champion Ukraine and the "Big Five" (France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom), competing in the final. Serbia, the UK, and Germany placed at the bottom, with Germany receiving just 18 points and the UK scoring 24.

The juries awarded Sweden an impressive 340 points, significantly more than Italy, which came in second with 177 points. Sweden's score included multiple 12-point awards, the maximum given by juries. Finland, represented by Käärijä, received 150 points from the juries, securing fifth place, while also winning the public vote with 243 points, edging out Sweden.

The influence of the jury system drew criticism on social media, where users also alleged that Loreen's song "Tattoo" bore similarities to other tracks, including "Flying Free" by Marc Escudero and Ruben Moreno, and songs by various artists.

The UK hosted Eurovision on behalf of Ukraine, the contest’s 2022 winner, amid Russia's ongoing invasion. Ukrainian duo Tvorchi finished sixth with 243 points; their performance occurred shortly after a missile strike near their hometown in Ukraine.

As a result of her triumph, Sweden is set to host the Eurovision Song Contest in 2024. Loreen initially won for Sweden in 2012 with "Euphoria," making her the first woman to achieve two Eurovision victories and only the second artist ever, following Ireland's Johnny Logan, who won in 1980 and 1987.
question:
Who became the first woman to win the Eurovision Song Contest twice with her recent victory in Liverpool?  
  
A) Conchita Wurst  
B) Loreen  
C) Dana International  
D) Céline Dion

title: Scientists: Rock that hit New Jersey home is 4.6 billion-year-old meteorite
content:
Scientists confirmed on Thursday that a rock weighing approximately 2.2 pounds, which fell onto a home in New Jersey on May 8, is indeed a meteorite, with an estimated age of 4.56 billion years.

Suzy Kop brought the rock to experts for examination to ascertain if it was an extraterrestrial object. Shannon Graham and Nathan Magee from the College's physics department conducted tests that included measuring the rock's density and analyzing its composition using a specialized instrument.

Initial assessments indicated that the rock is classified as a chondrite, a type of stony meteorite that contains small amounts of iron. While police initially hypothesized that the meteorite was linked to a nearby meteor shower, Sky & Telescope later determined that this was not the case based on an analysis of the meteorite's trajectory.

Kop discovered the warm, black rock on her father's bedroom floor around 12:30 PM. She noticed two holes in the ceiling, which scientists confirmed were made by the meteorite upon its high-speed impact, causing it to bounce off the floor. Kop immediately contacted the police, who dispatched a hazmat team to assess the situation. They concluded that the rock was not dangerously radioactive.

Fortunately, there were no injuries reported as a result of the impact.
question:
What is the estimated age of the meteorite that fell on a home in New Jersey on May 8? 

A) 2.2 billion years  
B) 3.5 billion years  
C) 4.56 billion years  
D) 5.0 billion years

title: Sudan warring forces sign agreement to protect civilians, aid workers
content:
Representatives from Sudan's warring factions, including the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), signed a declaration of principles on Thursday in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, pledging to ensure the safety of civilians, aid workers, and humanitarian efforts.

The declaration outlined their commitment to "ensuring the protection of civilians at all times," which includes allowing safe passage for civilians to exit conflict zones voluntarily, in the direction of their choosing.

Additionally, the agreement mandated that armed forces vacate public and private properties, such as hospitals and energy facilities, and emphasized the importance of treating the deceased with dignity.

The United Nations (UN) Special Representative in Sudan commented on Friday, "The most significant aspect of the agreement reached last night is the commitment from both sides to continue their discussions."

A U.S. representative involved in brokering the agreement clarified, "This is not a ceasefire; it is an affirmation of their obligations under international humanitarian law, particularly regarding civilian protection and the need to provide space for humanitarian operations."

Cameron Hudson from the U.S. Institute of Peace criticized the agreement, stating, "These are actions they should have been taking already without needing to be instructed. They should not receive credit for this." He expressed concern about the RSF's ability to control their troops to prevent violations of the agreement.

Humanitarian organizations, including the UN, have previously halted operations in the capital, Khartoum, and Darfur due to escalating violence. Since the conflict erupted on April 15, over 750 people have died, including at least 18 aid workers.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees reported that approximately 200,000 individuals have fled the country, while around 700,000 have been displaced internally.

During a human rights-focused summit in Geneva, Switzerland, Western nations condemned both the RSF and the army for committing human rights violations.
question:
What did the representatives from Sudan's warring factions agree to in the declaration of principles signed in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia?  

A) A ceasefire to end hostilities  
B) The protection of civilians and safe passage for them  
C) The appointment of a new military leader  
D) The immediate resumption of humanitarian activities

title: Tensions increase as US recovers downed Chinese "spy balloon" debris
content:
On Monday, the United States announced that a "significant" part of the payload from a Chinese balloon that was shot down over the Atlantic Ocean on February 4 had been recovered.

Officials stated on February 9 that the balloon was "likely capable of collecting and geo-locating communications" after a section of its wreckage was sent to a Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) lab for analysis. They accused China of conducting an espionage program aimed at over 40 countries, linking the balloon to this initiative.

China confirmed ownership of the balloon, asserting that it was a meteorological research craft that had been blown off its intended course by strong winds.

US officials believe the balloon entered US airspace on January 28. On February 3, Pentagon Press Secretary Brigadier General Pat Ryder stated that the balloon was drifting eastward at approximately 60,000 feet (18,300 meters) above the central United States and had demonstrated the ability to maneuver using motors and propellers.

Ryder noted that the balloon was "well above civilian air traffic" and assessed that it did not pose a physical threat to people on the ground. The presidential press secretary described the balloon's flight path over the United States as a "clear violation of our sovereignty."

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken canceled a planned trip to Beijing, which was scheduled for late February 4, following a call during which he labeled the balloon's presence in US airspace an "irresponsible act." The trip was intended to address issues of communication and easing tensions between the two nations.

Advisors informed President Joe Biden that the military should wait until the balloon was over water before shooting it down to avoid endangering civilians. He authorized its downing on February 4 as it floated off the coast of South Carolina.

China criticized the downing as "an obvious overreaction and a serious violation of international practice," stating that it reserves "the right to take further actions in response."

Emerging from a meeting while traveling to Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland, Biden praised the military efforts, saying: "They successfully took it down, and I want to compliment our aviators who did it."

In addition, a second balloon was reported flying over Latin America. On February 3, Ryder confirmed the sighting, stating, "We now assess it is another Chinese surveillance balloon."

On February 6, China also acknowledged the second balloon's presence, claiming it was another civilian weather balloon that had been pushed off course by wind.

US officials noted that this is not the first incident involving balloons crossing into US airspace, alleging that at least three such occurrences happened during Donald Trump's presidency and another during Biden's, although these flights were shorter in duration.
question:
What did US officials claim about the capabilities of the Chinese balloon that was shot down over the Atlantic Ocean?  

A) It had no ability to maneuver.  
B) It was likely capable of collecting and geo-locating communications.  
C) It was a civilian weather balloon.  
D) It was only a threat to military installations.

title: US actress and model Raquel Welch dies at age 82
content:
US actress and model Raquel Welch passed away yesterday in Los Angeles, California, as confirmed by her manager, Stephen LaManna. She was 82 years old and had been battling a brief illness.

Welch was one of the most prominent actresses of her era, boasting a remarkable career that included 30 films and 50 television roles.

Born Jo-Raquel Tejada in Chicago, Illinois, in 1940, Welch grew up in California, where she excelled in teenage beauty pageants and later worked as a local weather forecaster. 

After a divorce and while raising two children, she moved to Texas, where she pursued modeling and worked as a cocktail waitress. 

In 1964, Welch returned to California and made notable cameos in the drama "A Swingin' Summer" and the musical "Fathom," which marked the start of her ascent to stardom.

Her iconic role as a bikini-clad cavewoman in the 1966 film "One Million Years B.C." catapulted her to international fame. In the 1970s, her compelling performance in the classic film "The Last of Sheila" earned her an Academy Award nomination.

Throughout her career, Welch often expressed discomfort with the sexualization of her body. In her autobiography, "Raquel: Beyond the Cleavage," she reflected, "The irony of it all is that, even though people thought of me as a sex symbol, in reality I was a single mother of two small children."
question:
What was Raquel Welch's age at the time of her death?  

A) 72 years old  
B) 75 years old  
C) 80 years old  
D) 82 years old

title: Bangladesh President-elect meets outgoing president Hamid at Bangabhaban
content:
On Tuesday, Bangladesh's President-elect, Chuppu, met with outgoing President Abdul Hamid at the presidential palace, Bangabhaban, in Dhaka. This meeting follows the election commission's announcement on Monday that Chuppu will become Bangladesh's 22nd president.

An official from Bangabhaban reported that Chuppu was warmly welcomed by President Hamid and the First Lady, who presented him with a bouquet during this courtesy call. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and her sister were also present at the visit.

Chuppu ran as an independent candidate but was backed by the ruling Awami League (AL) party, securing the presidency without any challengers. The AL holds a majority in the 350-seat national parliament, with 302 members.

The parliamentary opposition, the Jatiya Party, opted not to nominate any candidate for the presidential election, while the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), which is outside parliament, could not nominate a candidate after all its members resigned in December 2022.

The presidential election nomination process concluded on Sunday, and the election is set for February 19.

Born in 1949, Chuppu is a veteran of the 1971 Liberation War and hailed from northern Bangladesh. He was a prominent student leader in the 1960s and 1970s and has served as a retired district judge and a member of the Awami League's Advisory Council.

Chuppu's inauguration is scheduled for April 24, 2023.

What is the scheduled date for Chuppu's inauguration as the president of Bangladesh?  

A) February 19, 2023  
B) April 24, 2023  
C) December 2022
