title: European Council agrees to crypto asset regulations
content:
The European Council, representing EU member states, approved the Markets in Crypto Assets (MiCA) regulations on Tuesday, marking the first comprehensive regulatory framework of its kind globally, according to Reuters.

Following the European Parliament's approval in April, MiCA will roll out in phases beginning July 2024, after being in legislative discussion since 2020.

Swedish Finance Minister, speaking on behalf of the Council presidency, emphasized the pressing need for these rules, stating, "Recent events have highlighted the urgent requirement to implement regulations that will better protect European investors and prevent the misuse of the crypto industry for money laundering and financing terrorism."

The new regulations mandate that companies involved in issuing, trading, and insuring crypto assets obtain a license to operate within the EU. Entities found to be noncompliant could face public naming and shaming by the bloc.

Designed to ensure market stability while curbing manipulation, MiCA will also hold firms accountable for losses, requiring them to disclose risks and fees to investors, as reported by the Associated Press.

Starting in January 2026, companies will be required to record parties involved in crypto transfers, aiding enforcement of taxation and anti-money laundering efforts.

Furthermore, MiCA aims to enhance cooperation among member states regarding crypto taxation.

This approval comes on the heels of a series of collapses within the crypto sector, including notable exchanges and the collapse of certain stablecoins, prompting calls for consistent international regulations.

The United Kingdom has expressed its intention to regulate stablecoins and is currently reviewing feedback on proposed policies.

In the United States, Hester Peirce, a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission, noted that various government officials are examining their roles in the crypto market, stating at a conference, "We are wandering in the desert a bit."
question:
What year is the phased rollout of the Markets in Crypto Assets (MiCA) regulations scheduled to begin?  

A) 2024  
B) 2025  
C) 2026  
D) 2023

title: Tennessee, US former police officers plead not guilty in Tyre Nichols' death
content:
Five former police officers charged in connection with the fatal beating of 29-year-old Tyre Nichols last month in Tennessee pleaded not guilty in court yesterday.

Demetrius Haley, Tadarrius Bean, Justin Smith, Emmitt Martin III, and Desmond Mills, Jr., who are all out on bail, face multiple charges, including second-degree murder, aggravated kidnapping, aggravated assault, official misconduct, and official oppression.

Criminal Court Judge James Jones has scheduled the next hearing for May 1. "We understand that there may be heightened emotions surrounding this case," Jones said. "However, we ask for your continued patience as the proceedings move forward."

The confrontation began on January 7 when officers stopped Nichols as he was returning home from work, alleging he was driving recklessly. Video footage shows Haley pulling Nichols out of his vehicle before officers shouted commands at him. Nichols attempted to communicate but ultimately fled. Smith, Bean, and Mills, Jr. apprehended him while Haley kicked him. Mills allegedly struck Nichols with a baton during the altercation.

One officer later claimed that Nichols attempted to grab his firearm during the struggle. 

According to police documents, Haley took photos of the cuffed and visibly injured Nichols using his cellphone and shared one with multiple recipients. Nichols was transported to St. Francis Hospital in critical condition but succumbed to his injuries on January 10.

Following the incident, all five officers were dismissed from the force and subsequently indicted. The police unit they belonged to, known as SCORPION, was disbanded. 

Additionally, two other officers were relieved of their duties, and seven more are under investigation. The Memphis Fire Department terminated three emergency medical technicians for failing to treat Nichols' injuries, and two county sheriff's deputies present at the incident were suspended.

Van Turner, President of the Memphis Branch of the NAACP, stated, "If you were an officer or first responder and you watched this young man die without providing any assistance, you are just as responsible as the individuals who assaulted him."

Nichols' family, their legal team, and local activists are calling for justice in response to his tragic death.
question:
What charges were brought against the five former police officers accused of fatally beating Tyre Nichols?  

A) First-degree murder and unlawful imprisonment  
B) Second-degree murder, aggravated kidnapping, aggravated assault, official misconduct, and official oppression  
C) Manslaughter and excessive force  
D) Assault and battery

title: Bulgarian police arrest four over eighteen dead migrants in abandoned truck
content:
Bulgarian authorities reported on Friday that police uncovered the bodies of eighteen deceased migrants, including a child, in an abandoned truck in Lokorsko, situated northeast of the capital, Sofia.

In connection with the incident, four individuals have been arrested, and 34 others—including five children—were taken to the hospital, with some in critical but stable condition. This tragedy is believed to be the deadliest incident involving migrants in Bulgaria to date, with survivors described as "freezing, wet, and having not eaten for several days."

The truck, which was carrying timber, concealed the migrants in hidden compartments. Health Minister Asen Medzhidiev informed reporters that the individuals inside suffered from a lack of oxygen, while Borislav Sarafov, head of the Bulgarian National Police, noted that some migrants may have suffocated.

Authorities suspect the migrants are from Afghanistan and had been en route to Serbia, taking a path commonly used by Middle Eastern migrants seeking to enter the European Union. Sarafov mentioned that the migrants entered Bulgaria illegally via Turkey and had spent two days in the woods before boarding the truck.

One of the individuals arrested had previously been convicted of human trafficking. Bulgarian official Atanas Ilkov stated that charges are pending as further evidence is gathered.

In December, Austria and the Netherlands blocked Bulgaria's bid to join the Schengen Area, citing a rise in asylum-seekers entering via the Western Balkans and concerns over the government's handling of crime.

Both Bulgaria and its northern neighbor Romania, which also faced opposition from Austria regarding its accession, are located along the Western Balkan route for migration—a situation disputed by Bucharest.

According to the EU's external border control agency, 61,375 migrants entered the EU via this route in 2021, primarily through Bulgaria or Greece, with common destinations including Croatia, Hungary, Romania, and Serbia.

The Bulgarian Ministry of the Interior reported that over 12,740 migrants were detained in the first nine months of 2022, and the number of attempted border crossings from January to August doubled to 80,000 compared to figures from 2021.
question:
What was the outcome of the incident involving the abandoned truck discovered in Lokorsko, Bulgaria?  

A) 34 migrants were rescued without injuries.  
B) Eighteen migrants were found dead, including a child.  
C) The truck was carrying food supplies for the migrants.  
D) Only two migrants were arrested in connection with the truck.

title: Study: floods, droughts more intense in past 20 years due to higher global temperatures
content:
On Monday, a study conducted by two NASA scientists revealed a significant link between climate change and the increasing severity of water-related extreme weather events, such as floods and droughts, over the past two decades. 

Authors Matthew Rodell and Bailing Li concluded that rising temperatures are likely driving an increase in the total intensity of hydroclimatic extremes, which cannot be solely attributed to the regular variations in climate. The study identified 1,066 regions that experienced either excessive or insufficient rainfall from 2002 to 2021, utilizing a new algorithm based on observations from satellite data.

The researchers classified these regions into 505 'wet' clusters and 561 'dry' clusters, discovering a notable rise in the severity of extreme weather events in the seven years following 2015, which is recognized as one of the warmest periods in recorded history. Between 2015 and 2021, the number of 'most extreme' events—defined as the top 30 wettest or driest—rose from three to four per year.

The study also observed an increase in the wet-to-dry event ratio in regions between 15° and 20° N, while three areas between 15° N and 50° N saw a decrease. This supports the idea that extreme weather events have an inverse relationship in affecting wet and dry regions.

The most severe dry event recorded was a historic drought in South America from 2015 to 2016, whereas the most intense wet event spanned from 2002 to 2021 in sub-Saharan Africa, leading to unprecedented flooding and affecting homes and infrastructure. 

Rodell, the lead author, expressed surprise at how closely global intensity correlated with rising global temperatures. He stated, "We suspected this might be related to global warming, given that the last seven years have been the hottest on record. Our findings confirm a significant connection between the intensity of these events and temperature increases."

Regarding the reliability of the study, Rodell emphasized that global warming is likely to result in more frequent and severe wet and dry events. "While predicting regional impacts is more complex, the overall trend points toward intensified extremes."

Rodell added, "This study highlights how climate change is affecting everyone—not just through rising average temperatures but via increasingly severe weather events that directly impact communities."

Richard Seager, a climate specialist from Columbia University, noted the study's implications for future water resource management and flood control, underscoring the expectation that wetter extremes are likely to become wetter and drier extremes drier. "Everything will amplify on both sides of the dry-wet spectrum."

Park Williams, a researcher at the University of California, Los Angeles, remarked on the unprecedented ability to monitor continental water dynamics from space. He suggested this study could be pivotal for future generations seeking to understand humanity’s evolving comprehension of the planet.

Meanwhile, CNN quoted climatologist and director of Brown University’s Institute for Environment and Society, who described the study as offering a fresh perspective on the rapidly changing water cycle, connecting numerous headlines about droughts, floods, and wildfires to a global analysis. "This finding reinforces trends observed in rainfall data and climate models, providing crucial evidence for emergency planning, infrastructure development, agricultural practices, and water resource management amidst ongoing warming."

Rodell has been serving as the Acting Deputy Director of Earth Sciences at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center since 2021, while Li has worked as an assistant research scientist at the Hydrological Sciences Laboratory at Goddard since 2017.

According to the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a 2021 report indicated a 70% increase in the frequency of droughts typically expected to occur every decade and a 30% increase for similar flooding events. Scientists have also warned that global warming could intensify 'weather whiplash,' characterized by rapid extremes, as evidenced in California’s recent transitions from megadrought to heavy rainfall and snowstorms.

Current estimates suggest that droughts and floods account for 20% of annual weather-related losses in the U.S. economy.
question:
What was the primary conclusion of the study published by NASA scientists Matthew Rodell and Bailing Li regarding extreme weather events?

A) The increase in global temperatures is unrelated to the severity of weather events.  
B) The occurrence of extreme weather events has decreased in the past two decades.  
C) Rising temperatures are strongly linked to an increase in the severity and frequency of hydroclimatic extreme events.  
D) The number of wet events is outpacing the number of dry events globally.

title: US Interior Department approves Willow oil project in Alaska
content:
**US Approves Willow Project in Alaska's NPR-A**

On March 13, the US government approved the Willow Project within the National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska (NPR-A). The Department of the Interior revoked leases covering 68,000 acres (275 square kilometers) of land in the Bear Tooth Unit, located in northeastern NPR-A, while granting three of ConocoPhillips' five requested drilling sites.

According to the Department's statement, the approved plan aims to minimize environmental impact by requiring "the fewest ice roads, the least total miles of infield pipelines, minimal water use, and fewer vehicle, fixed-wing aircraft, and helicopter trips, along with fewer acres impacted."

Alaska Republican Senator expressed relief over the reapproval of the economically significant Willow Project, calling it a "huge and needed victory for all Alaska."

However, a January Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (SEIS) from the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) highlighted that the project is expected to destroy approximately 532 acres (2 square kilometers) of wetlands, consume around 1.5 billion gallons (5.7 billion liters) of freshwater, and emit approximately 613 trillion pounds (278,036 metric megatons) of gross greenhouse gases throughout its 30-year lifespan.

The development of the project master plan began in 2018, with the BLM initially releasing its Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) on August 15, 2020. On that same day, several indigenous and conservation organizations criticized the previous Trump administration for allegedly prioritizing ConocoPhillips' timeline over thorough community engagement and analysis.

The Department of the Interior issued a Record of Decision on October 26, 2020, authorizing up to three drill sites and the necessary supporting infrastructure, including processing facilities, gravel access roads, and pipelines. Secretary of the Interior emphasized that this decision would significantly contribute to oil flow through the Trans Alaska Pipeline while generating revenue and assistance for indigenous communities.

On February 13, 2021, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals temporarily halted ConocoPhillips' activities related to road construction and gravel mining for the project. Then, on August 18, 2021, the court overturned the August 2020 EIS, ruling it failed to assess foreign greenhouse gas emissions and did not consider alternative proposals adequately.

In January 2021, President Joe Biden signed an executive order pausing new oil and gas leases on public lands and offshore waters as part of his campaign platform. However, a federal judge reinstated lease sales, stating the administration lacked the authority to implement the pause.

The Inflation Reduction Act mandated the Department of the Interior to lease at least 60 million acres offshore and 2 million acres of federal lands each year for oil and gas development, as requested by the industry.

The Willow Project enjoys support from various Alaska Native organizations and Alaska's bipartisan congressional delegation, who assert that it is crucial for their communities. Another Alaska Republican Senator called it “one of the biggest, most important resource development projects in our state's history.” On February 20, the Alaska Legislature passed House Joint Resolution 6 in favor of the project, with a unanimous vote of 36–0.

In contrast, Senior Campaign Representative Mike Scott warned that the Willow Project would greatly harm public lands and the climate, describing its approval as a step backward, especially following the enactment of significant climate legislation.
question:
What is the size of the land area whose leases were revoked by the Department within the Bear Tooth Unit as part of the Willow Project approval?  

A) 68,000 acres  
B) 532 acres  
C) 1.5 billion gallons  
D) 2 million acres

title: Paris judge acquits Airbus, Air France of involuntary manslaughter in 2009 crash that killed 228
content:
On Monday, a Paris judge acquitted Airbus of involuntary manslaughter in connection with the 2009 crash of Air France Flight 447 (AF447), which resulted in the deaths of all 228 individuals onboard. This ruling marked a significant moment as it concluded the first involuntary manslaughter trial in French history.

Judge Sylvie Daunis indicated that Airbus had faced charges four times, while Air France had been charged once. Nevertheless, she reaffirmed the civil liability of both companies, highlighting that Air France had already compensated victims' families. A hearing concerning further civil damages has been scheduled for September 4.

If convicted, Airbus and Air France could have faced fines of up to €225,000 each. In the fourth quarter of 2022, Air France reported €7.1 billion in revenue, while Airbus announced €20.64 billion for the same period. Reports suggest that both companies have also settled to transfer undisclosed amounts.

Claire Durousseau, whose niece was among the 216 passengers from 33 countries aboard AF447, expressed her distress after the verdict, stating, "Our lost ones have died a second time. I feel sick." Danièle Lamy, president of the victims' families' association Entraide et Solidarité AF447, stated that after a decade of "chaotic" legal disputes, including a nine-week trial last year, families felt "mortified and overwhelmed." She lamented that "the loser first and foremost is French justice."

Attorney Alain Jakubowicz, representing the victims' families, remarked, "We're told Air France and Airbus are responsible, but not guilty. We were waiting for the word 'guilty.'"

Both defendants expressed their condolences to the families and reiterated their commitment to aviation safety. The plaintiffs, comprised of victims' family members, noted that the prosecution had argued for acquittal, citing insufficient evidence to hold the corporations liable instead of the pilots.

Air France has maintained that the exact causes of the accident remain unknown. Judge Daunis found Airbus negligent for failing to replace the model of the external airspeed sensors, which had been involved in prior incidents, as well as for not correlating incident reports from airlines to identify the issue with the pitot tubes. The judge noted that Airbus had not informed pilots about these issues to the same extent it communicated with other stakeholders. Investigators relied on encoded alerts to analyze the accident's causes before the main wreckage was located in 2011.

The judge also determined that Air France acted negligently by failing to remind pilots of previous problems with the pitot tubes. AF447, en route from Rio de Janeiro to Paris, crashed into the Atlantic Ocean on May 31, 2009. The main wreckage was discovered by remotely operated submarines on April 3, 2011, approximately 13,000 feet underwater, and the Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA) retrieved the aircraft's black boxes the following month.

BEA investigators determined that ice had accumulated on the pitots, disabling the autopilot and leading to a stall, which triggered warnings that the pilots ultimately ignored. Airbus has concurred with this explanation.

Air France, the National Airline Pilots Union, and Entraide et Solidarité AF447 criticized the BEA for allegedly focusing its investigation on the airline rather than thoroughly examining Airbus's role in the accident.

The AF447 crash has prompted new regulations regarding sensor testing and pilot training.
question:
What was the outcome of the trial regarding Airbus and Air France in connection with the 2009 crash of Air France Flight 447?  

A) Airbus and Air France were found guilty of involuntary manslaughter.  
B) Airbus and Air France were found not guilty of involuntary manslaughter.  
C) Airbus was fined €225,000.  
D) Air France paid €20 billion in reparations.

title: Former South Carolina governor Nikki Haley declares bid for 2024 US presidential election
content:
**Nikki Haley Announces Presidential Candidacy for 2024 Election**

Last Tuesday, former South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley declared her candidacy for the Republican nomination in the 2024 United States presidential election.

Haley, who previously served as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, is preparing to challenge her former boss, Donald Trump, the last Republican president. Additionally, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, U.S. Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, former Vice President Mike Pence, and former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo are also expected to announce their bids for the nomination. Current polls indicate that Haley is trailing both Trump and DeSantis.

In her announcement video titled "Strong & Proud," Haley stated, "Republicans have lost the popular vote in seven of the last eight presidential elections. That has to change." She criticized President Joe Biden’s administration, asserting that “the Washington establishment has failed us over and over again,” and emphasized the need for “a new generation of leadership,” declaring, “I’m Nikki Haley, and I’m running for president.”

Haley held her opening rally on Wednesday in South Carolina, where, according to Politico, the atmosphere was more subdued compared to Trump's typically energetic campaign events.

Taylor Budowich, a spokesperson for Trump’s political action committee, Make America Great Again Inc., dismissed Haley as "just another career politician," reminding voters that she began her career in politics before resigning to join the Trump administration. “Now, she's claiming to represent a 'new generation.' It looks like the same old story — a career politician whose primary commitment is to herself,” Budowich remarked.

At 51, Haley framed her candidacy in contrast to Biden, 80, and Trump, 76, advocating for "mandatory mental competency tests for politicians over 75 years" and encouraging a departure from "stale ideas and faded names of the past." She added, "America is not past our prime; it’s just that our politicians are past theirs."

Born Nimrata Nikki Randhawa in South Carolina to Indian immigrants, Haley highlighted her background in her announcement video, stating, "I was the proud daughter of Indian immigrants: not Black, not white. I was different." If she secures the nomination, Haley would be both the first female and the first non-white Republican presidential nominee, and if elected, the first female president and the first of Indian descent in U.S. history.

Haley's political career began in 2004 when she won her first race by defeating one of the longest-serving South Carolina state representatives. In 2010, she made history as the first non-white female governor of a U.S. state. She was reelected in 2014 and delivered the Republican rebuttal to President Barack Obama’s address in 2016.

Following a racially charged shooting in 2015, Haley attended the victims’ funerals and successfully advocated for the removal of a Confederate flag from the state capitol. She publicly criticized Trump for his failure to condemn the Ku Klux Klan during his 2016 campaign but later expressed her support for him as president.

In 2017, Trump appointed Haley as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations. During her tenure, the U.S. withdrew from several international agreements that she deemed to be anti-Israel. Haley resigned in late 2018, with both her and the administration citing other reasons for her departure, although Trump claimed it was planned six months in advance due to internal disagreements over Russia sanctions.
question:
What significant announcement did former South Carolina governor Nikki Haley make last Tuesday?  

A) She announced her retirement from politics.  
B) She declared her intention to seek the Republican nomination for the 2024 presidential election.  
C) She endorsed Donald Trump for the 2024 election.  
D) She announced her candidacy for the position of US ambassador to the United Nations.

title: Sinn Féin becomes largest party in Northern Ireland local government after 2023 elections
content:
Sinn Féin emerged as the top party across Northern Ireland’s eleven councils as the counting concluded on Saturday. 

The nationalist party secured 144 of the 462 contested seats, an increase from 105 in the previous elections, which allowed them to surpass the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which retained its 122 seats from 2019. 

The Alliance Party came in third, boosting its total from 53 to 67 seats. The Ulster Unionist Party won 54 seats, while the Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP) garnered 39 seats. The remaining 36 seats were distributed among independent candidates and smaller parties.

A total of 807 candidates competed in these elections. Sinn Féin claimed the most seats in six councils, whereas the DUP remained the largest party in five councils.

Local councils in Northern Ireland are responsible for setting tax rates, planning development, and providing essential services, including waste management and public park maintenance.

Due to the terms of the 1998 Good Friday Agreement, the largest nationalist and unionist parties must cooperate to form a government in semi-autonomous Northern Ireland. However, the government has been suspended since the resignation of DUP First Minister Jeffrey Givan in February 2022, who stepped down in opposition to Brexit-related trade checks on goods moving from the rest of the UK to Northern Ireland.

Givan’s resignation was rooted in his discontent with the Northern Ireland protocol, which allowed for an open border with the EU member Ireland while imposing checks on goods from the rest of the UK. The UK and EU proposed adjustments to these checks in February, but the DUP rejected them.

In the May 2022 elections for the Assembly, Sinn Féin surpassed the DUP to become the largest party for the first time, an achievement that reflected growing nationalist sentiment.

Sinn Féin's vice president, Michelle O'Neill, stated that the election results signify a demand for effective leadership and a push to reactivate the Assembly. She urged joint efforts from both the UK and Ireland to resolve the current political impasse.

DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson remarked that the party seeks a mandate to negotiate changes to existing trade rules, emphasizing the importance of safeguarding Northern Ireland's trading relationship with the rest of the UK and restoring its place within the union.
question:
What was the total number of seats won by Sinn Féin in the recent elections across Northern Ireland's councils?  

A) 122  
B) 144  
C) 105  
D) 67

title: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy denies Russian claim of capture of Bakhmut
content:
**Zelenskyy Addresses Press Amid Ongoing Battle for Bakhmut at G7 Summit**

On Sunday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy spoke to reporters at the G7 summit in Hiroshima, Japan, asserting that the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut remains contested despite Russian claims of full occupation. "We are persevering; we are fighting," he stated. 

Through an interpreter, Zelenskyy emphasized the importance of human life, saying, “We are not sacrificing our people [...] People are our treasure. While I understand the situation in Bakhmut clearly, I cannot divulge the technical details of our operations." 

His comments come in the wake of a statement from Yevgeny Prigozhin, the leader of the pro-Russian Wagner Group, who claimed in a Telegram video that his forces captured Bakhmut shortly before noon on Saturday. Surrounded by troops amid scenes of destruction, Prigozhin noted, “We faced not only the Ukrainian armed forces in Bakhmut but also Russian bureaucracy, which has hindered our efforts."

Ukraine’s Deputy Defense Minister responded to these claims, stating that while "the situation is critical," Ukrainian forces continue to hold strategic positions in Bakhmut. “Our defenders control key industrial and infrastructure sites in the area,” she noted, adding that Ukrainian troops managed to create a semi-encirclement of the city. "The enemy failed to surround Bakhmut and has lost key elevations around it. Our advancing forces in the suburbs are complicating the enemy's position."

Earlier in the day, Zelenskyy’s press secretary made comments regarding the potential fall of Bakhmut, which were later retracted. Zelenskyy had remarked, "I believe it has not fallen, but you must understand—there is nothing left; they have destroyed everything. It is tragic." He described the current state of Bakhmut as a desolate landscape filled with devastation.

Serhii Cherevatyi, a spokesperson for the Ukrainian Eastern Group of Forces, corroborated the president's assessment, stating that while the city has been largely reduced to rubble, Ukrainian forces are inflicting heavy damage on the enemy through artillery and air strikes. "Our troops are still holding positions in the southwestern part of the city, and heavy fighting continues," he added.

Hours before Zelenskyy’s comments, Russian President Vladimir Putin praised Wagner forces and the support of the Russian Armed Forces, claiming they had completed operations to "liberate" Bakhmut, referencing the city's Soviet-era name, Artyomovsk.

A Washington, D.C.-based military analyst contended that Russia's announced capture of Bakhmut holds little tactical significance, as it does not provide substantial operational advantage for future offensives or defenses against potential Ukrainian counterattacks. Other analysts mentioned that while Bakhmut’s fall could offer some tactical benefit to Moscow, it is unlikely to serve as a decisive turning point in the war.

Zelenskyy previously warned that losing Bakhmut could undermine Ukraine's position in negotiations for a settlement, potentially persuading the international community to support a compromise that Ukraine cannot accept.

The battle for Bakhmut, which began with Russian assaults in August, has been fierce, with Ukrainian troops initially repelling the attacks. In January, Russian forces captured Soledar, a nearby salt-mining town.

Amid rising casualties—where reports indicated Russia's death rate in Bakhmut was five times that of Ukraine—the fight has been described by Wagner forces as a "meat grinder." Videos circulating online have sparked outrage, allegedly showing brutal acts by Russian soldiers against Ukrainians, prompting Ukraine's Foreign Minister to call for the removal of "Russian terrorists" from the UN.

Zelenskyy drew parallels between the devastation in Bakhmut and the historical destruction seen in Hiroshima, the target of the first atomic bombing during World War II.

Later at the summit, Zelenskyy held a press conference alongside U.S. President Joe Biden, who announced an additional $375 million in military aid for Ukraine, which includes artillery and vehicles. Zelenskyy expressed gratitude for the substantial support from the U.S. on Twitter.

Additionally, the U.S. has indicated that Ukrainian forces may soon begin training on its fighter jets, signaling a potential future transfer of F-16s to Ukraine. Biden affirmed that Zelenskyy assured he would not deploy these jets against Russia.

Before the war, Bakhmut was known for its tourism and production in underground caves, specifically mining salt and gypsum.
question:
What did Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy claim about the situation in Bakhmut during the G7 summit in Hiroshima?  

A) Bakhmut has been completely captured by Russian forces.  
B) Ukrainian forces are in full control of the city.  
C) Bakhmut remains contested, with ongoing fighting.  
D) Bakhmut is currently not significant in the conflict.

title: Russia sentences opposition activist Vladimir Kara-Murza to 25 years in penal colony
content:
On Monday, a judge in Moscow sentenced political activist Vladimir Kara-Murza to 25 years in a "strict regime correctional colony." He was convicted on charges of treason, associating with an "undesirable" entity, and disseminating false information about the military. In addition to his prison sentence, Kara-Murza was fined 400,000 rubles (approximately US$4,900).

Kara-Murza holds dual citizenship in Russia and the United Kingdom. In response to the sentencing, the UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office summoned the Russian Ambassador. Foreign Secretary James Cleverly stated, "Vladimir Kara-Murza bravely denounced Russia's invasion of Ukraine for what it was—a blatant violation of international law and the UN Charter."

The UN Commissioner for Human Rights condemned the conviction as "another blow to the rule of law and civic space in the Russian Federation." Both Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International also criticized the ruling, which the judge issued in just minutes.

Diplomats and foreign journalists were barred from the courtroom but were permitted to observe the proceedings via screens from an adjacent room in the courthouse.

In his statement during the court proceedings, Kara-Murza said, "I know that the day will come when the darkness engulfing our country will dissipate. This day will come as inevitably as spring comes to replace even the frostiest winter."

A Russian spokesperson declined to comment on the case when approached by the Associated Press.

The charges against Kara-Murza included references to a speech he delivered to Arizona legislators in March 2022, during which he accused Russia of committing war crimes in Ukraine, including the bombing of maternity hospitals and schools. His claims were independently verified by the BBC, but Russian authorities labeled them as "false information."

Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the government introduced criminal penalties for spreading false information about its military actions.

Kara-Murza has previously survived poisoning attempts in 2015 and 2017. He was an associate of opposition leader Boris Nemtsov, who was assassinated in 2015.
question:
What was the main reason for Vladimir Kara-Murza's sentencing by a Moscow judge?  
  
A) Associating with a foreign government  
B) Treason and disseminating false information about the military  
C) Insulting the Russian president  
D) Leading anti-government protests

title: Coolum win tier 1 women’s cricket premiership on Australia’s Sunshine Coast
content:
Coolum clinched the premiership title in the top tier of women's cricket on Australia's Sunshine Coast on Sunday, defeating Hinterland by 83 runs in the Grand Final.

Batting first, Coolum posted a solid total of 181 runs for the loss of 3 wickets in their allotted 30 overs. In response, Hinterland managed to score just 98 runs, losing 8 wickets in the process.

Coolum's captain, Sammy Franks, expressed her pride in the team’s performance: "The girls played incredibly well today. Scoring 181 with the bat is quite an achievement. We aimed for 140 to 150 runs, so reaching 181 was wonderful."

Following the match, two senior Coolum players, Kerry Cowling and Paula McKie, announced their retirement from cricket.

Franks reflected on the emotional victory, stating, "It was fantastic to win and give Kezza and Paula a proper farewell. Paula is retiring as well, which was a bit of a secret. She’s moving on to bigger and better things, and we will miss her. As vice captain, she was an invaluable resource and always there for me."

She continued to praise Cowling’s contributions: "Kerry has done so much for the club, often behind the scenes. From cleaning the toilets to bringing sausages for the team, she handled all the administrative tasks and really acted like a cricket mum to us."
question:
What was the final score difference by which Coolum won the Grand Final against Hinterland?

title: US President Biden signals support for bill to repeal authorizations for use of military force against Iraq
content:
On March 16, President Joe Biden expressed his support for a Senate bill aimed at repealing the authorizations for the use of military force (AUMF) against Iraq.

In a Statement of Administration Policy, Biden stated that the proposed bill, S. 316, would have "no impact" on current military operations, noting that no actions "rely primarily on the 2002 AUMF."

The Senate is expected to vote on S. 316 within the next week. If passed, the bill would effectively terminate the 2002 AUMF, stripping future presidents of the authority to use it as a basis for military actions in Iraq and beyond. Truthout characterized this move as a "symbolic end" to U.S. military involvement in Iraq.

The 1991 AUMF authorized the Gulf War, while the 2002 AUMF was established for the Iraq War. Both have been invoked by various U.S. presidents to justify military actions, including operations in Syria.

On June 17, 2021, the House of Representatives approved a repeal of the 2002 AUMF; however, that bill did not make it through the Senate. Democratic Representative **Barbara Lee** emphasized the importance of repeal, stating, "The executive branch has a history of stretching the 2002 AUMF's legal authority." A separate resolution to withdraw all U.S. troops from Syria failed in the House on March 8.

Introduced on February 9, S. 316 has garnered 45 co-sponsors and passed through the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by a vote of 13–8 on March 8.

Republican Senator **Mitt Romney** from Utah expressed caution, stating, "The world continues to be a troubled place, and I don't want to remove any authorities that may be necessary to defend our interests." Florida Republican Senator **Marco Rubio** echoed similar sentiments, indicating that he does not want to limit the President's capability to conduct military operations, referencing the U.S. killing of Iranian General Qasem Soleimani in 2020.

In a CNN editorial published on Saturday, Representative Lee and Bridget Moix, general secretary of the Quaker nonprofit **Friends Committee on National Legislation**, asserted, "[B]y allowing the authorization to remain on the books, lawmakers in Congress are also abdicating a core constitutional responsibility." They emphasized that the U.S. founders entrusted Congress with the power to declare war to prevent unilateral decision-making by any single individual.

Notably, Barbara Lee was the only member of Congress to vote against the AUMF authorizing military action in Afghanistan following the September 11 attacks.
question:
What does US Senate bill S. 316 aim to repeal?  

A) The 1991 and 2002 authorizations for use of military force (AUMF)  
B) The military actions in Syria  
C) The authorization for military action in Afghanistan  
D) The use of military force against Russia

title: African Union summit closes; bloc reaffirms member suspensions, support for trade deal
content:
The African Union (AU) concluded its annual summit on Sunday in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, following two days of discussions. During the summit, leaders reaffirmed their commitment to maintain the suspensions of four member states—Burkina Faso, Guinea, Mali, and Sudan—which are currently governed by military regimes. The AU also emphasized the need to "accelerate the implementation" of the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA).

Bankole Adeoye, the AU Commissioner for Political Affairs, Peace and Security, stated that the organization maintains a "zero tolerance" policy toward coups but is prepared to assist these nations in returning to constitutional governance.

Launched in 2020, the AfCFTA has encountered challenges, particularly due to disputes over tariff reductions and the impact of COVID-19 pandemic-related border closures. All 55 African nations, except Eritrea, are participants in the AfCFTA, which is regarded as the world's largest free trade area by population. Currently, only 15% of trade occurs within Africa, a figure the AfCFTA aims to boost to 60% by 2034.

In a related development, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) announced on Sunday that it will uphold stringent trade restrictions and sanctions against Mali, with lesser measures against Guinea and Burkina Faso. Additionally, ECOWAS plans to implement travel bans on the leaders and officials of these countries. The organization is advocating for a return to civilian rule by 2024 in Burkina Faso and Mali, and by 2025 in Guinea.
question:
What decision did the African Union summit make regarding its suspended members? 

A) They agreed to lift the suspensions of all four members.  
B) They decided to increase sanctions against the suspended members.  
C) They agreed to preserve the suspensions of four AU members.  
D) They voted to expel the suspended members from the AU.

title: Reports: 'streamlined' UK asylum process to replace interview with questionnaire for five nationalities
content:
**UK to Implement Questionnaires for Refugee Status Determination Amid Backlog Challenges**

The United Kingdom will begin using questionnaires instead of traditional interviews to assess the refugee status of approximately 12,000 asylum seekers from Afghanistan, Eritrea, Libya, Syria, and Yemen who submitted their applications before last summer. This initiative is part of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's broader strategy to address the country's 92,000 asylum claim backlog by the end of the year.

While essential security, criminal, and health checks will still be conducted, officials will eliminate face-to-face interviews for applicants from five nationalities with a claim approval rate exceeding 95%. 

The questionnaires, ranging from ten to 32 pages and containing 40 to 50 questions, must be completed in English. Applicants are encouraged to use online translation tools if necessary. They are required to return the completed forms within 20 working days. A leaked internal letter obtained by Sky News indicates that failure to submit the questionnaire without a valid reason may result in withdrawal of an individual's asylum claim; however, the government will issue reminders and consider extensions beyond the deadline.

Officials assured BBC News that each claim will be assessed based on its merits, emphasizing that no one will be denied asylum solely based on their responses to the questionnaire.

This new process follows a similar fast-track system proposed for 3,000 Afghan refugees in September 2021, which was reportedly dismissed by former Prime Minister Boris Johnson due to concerns it could be perceived as amnesty, a characterisation the Home Office disputes, while also citing potential strain on the UK's welfare and housing systems.

Labour's Shadow Home Secretary, Yvette Cooper, expressed her party's support for the move, stating it is "damning" that the Home Office had not implemented such measures sooner, particularly for safe countries like Albania, as recommended by the United Nations two years ago. She added, "Labour has a common-sense plan to fast-track cases, establish return agreements for unsuccessful claims, and combat the criminal gangs facilitating perilous small boat crossings."

Data released today indicates that a record 45,756 migrants crossed the Channel in the past year, contributing to an unprecedented 150,000 outstanding asylum claims. Sunak has prioritised migration management, with new legislation set to be introduced next month to prevent illegal migrants from claiming asylum in the UK.

The Home Office letter suggests that the use of the questionnaire may be extended to gather additional information from other asylum seekers in the future, although there are no current plans for expansion of the scheme.

Home Secretary Suella Braverman stated, "We are facing an unsustainable situation in our towns and cities due to the overwhelming numbers of people arriving here illegally and our obligations to accommodate them."

The questionnaire approach has drawn criticism for potentially simplifying the asylum process for some applicants while creating barriers for those who may struggle with English or lack legal assistance. The Guardian highlighted instances of complex questions that could confuse applicants, such as inquiries about human trafficking and modern slavery.

Critics, including immigration barrister Colin Yeo and Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants campaigner Caitlin Boswell, have raised concerns that the government’s approach lacks sensitivity and could jeopardise individuals’ rights to refuge. Boswell stated, "People fleeing desperate circumstances need quicker and fairer asylum decisions, but this move is clumsy and could endanger their safety."

In response to the situation, Enver Solomon, CEO of a prominent refugee support organisation, called for a more thoughtful approach, warning that more bureaucratic obstacles and threats of application withdrawals are not the answer. He stressed that expecting individuals who have endured prolonged uncertainty to complete a lengthy English-only form in a short timeframe is neither fair nor reasonable.

On Wednesday, Sunak defended the government's record and suggested a "formal update" from Braverman is forthcoming, adding, "We are working intensely to advance this legislation [...] our deals with Albania and France are already proving beneficial [...] we want a system where individuals who arrive illegally will not be permitted to stay."
question:
What is the primary reason for the United Kingdom's decision to start issuing questionnaires instead of conducting official interviews for certain asylum seekers?

A) To increase the acceptance rate of asylum claims  
B) To streamline processing for specific nationalities with high acceptance rates  
C) To eliminate the backlog of all asylum claims  
D) To reduce the use of online translation tools

title: US condemns Russian Defense Minister for awarding pilots who intercepted US drone
content:
In a press briefing on Wednesday, White House National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby criticized Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu for awarding two Russian pilots for their involvement in the interception of a U.S. drone over the Black Sea.

Kirby stated, "I don’t know of another military in the world—another air force—that would commend a pilot for colliding with a drone. If that’s bravery, then they have a different definition of it. It’s ludicrous and insulting.”

He added that while it remains unclear if the pilot intentionally rammed the MQ-9 drone, video evidence was “pretty conclusive” regarding the incident.

On March 14, the United States Air Forces in Europe and Africa (USAFE-AFAFRICA) reported the incident, which occurred at 07:03 local time (06:03 UTC) over international waters, involving Russian SU-27 fighter jets.

General James Hecker, commander of USAFE-AFAFRICA, described the Russian actions as "reckless, environmentally unsound, and unprofessional," noting that the SU-27s dumped fuel on and flew dangerously close to the MQ-9 prior to the collision.

U.S. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller, speaking to MSNBC on March 15, suggested that the incident was likely unintentional, attributing it to "profound incompetence" on the part of the Russian pilots.

The following day, U.S. European Command (EUCOM) declassified a 42-second video clip from the incident, edited for length. The footage reportedly shows two passes over the drone, with the second pass allegedly resulting in a collision. After the collision, the video cuts out for approximately nine seconds before resuming, revealing damage to the drone's propeller.

EUCOM stated that the MQ-9's pilots intentionally crashed the drone into the sea due to the damage sustained.

In response, Russia denied any deliberate action to bring down the drone, asserting that the MQ-9's "sharp maneuvering" caused its crash.

Samir Puri, a visiting lecturer in war studies at King’s College London, told Al Jazeera that while the video doesn’t prove intent, he believes that Russian pilots would engage in aggressive flying to assert dominance in the airspace, indicating that the Americans cannot conduct intelligence flights without interference.

Russian Secretary of the Security Council Nikolai Patrushev claimed, "The Americans keep saying they're not taking part in military operations. This is the latest confirmation that they are directly participating in these activities—in the war."

The Guardian speculated that the incident could escalate tensions surrounding Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine.

Reports varied on the timing of Shoigu's award presentation, with CNN and others suggesting it occurred on March 17, while other outlets indicated it took place on Wednesday.

Shoigu's Ministry of Defense stated that the pilots "prevented the violation by the American MQ-9 unmanned aerial vehicle of the borders of the area of temporary regime for airspace use, established for the purpose of conducting a special military operation."
question:
What action did Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu take concerning two Russian pilots involved in an incident with a US drone over the Black Sea?  

A) He awarded them for their bravery.  
B) He reprimanded them for reckless behavior.  
C) He grounded them from flying.  
D) He ignored the incident.

title: Expedition locates wreck of World War II-sunk ship Montevideo Maru
content:
On Friday, Australian Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles announced via Twitter that a team from the Australia-based Silentworld Foundation has successfully located the wreck of the Montevideo Maru in the South China Sea. This Japanese merchant vessel was torpedoed by the United States in 1942 during World War II while transporting prisoners of war (POWs), resulting in the tragic loss of 1,080 lives.

The wreck was discovered northwest of Luzon in the Philippines, at a depth greater than that of the RMS Titanic.

The Silentworld team, which included deep-sea specialists from a Dutch company, conducted the search over twelve days using a remotely operated vehicle equipped with advanced technology.

On July 1, 1942, POWs captured in Rabaul, Papua New Guinea, were transferred to the Montevideo Maru, which was under Japanese occupation. Among the POWs were both military personnel and civilians from fourteen different countries, with 864 being Australians.

The ship was not marked as carrying POWs when it was struck; a United States Navy submarine mistakenly fired torpedoes at it, leading to its sinking.

The Silentworld Foundation has stated that there are currently no plans to recover human remains from the Montevideo Maru, but they are contemplating commemorative events for July 1 to honor the anniversary of the sinking.

"This discovery marks the end of one of the most tragic chapters in Australia's maritime history," Marles said. "Knowing the location of this wreck brings comfort and relief to many Australian families."

Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese added, "The extraordinary effort behind this discovery reflects our nation's solemn commitment to always remember and honor those who served our country."

Lieutenant General John Frewen expressed gratitude to the Silentworld team and the dedicated researchers, including those from the Unrecovered War Casualties team at the Army, for their perseverance in finding the final resting place of the Montevideo Maru. "A loss like this resonates through the decades and serves as a poignant reminder of the human cost of conflict," he stated.
question:
What was the name of the ship that was located in the South China Sea wreck, which was torpedoed by the United States during World War II?  
A) USS Arizona  
B) Montevideo Maru  
C) RMS Titanic  
D) HMAS Sydney

title: US political commentator Tucker Carlson, Fox News separate
content:
Today, Fox Media announced that Tucker Carlson is no longer with the company. Carlson has hosted a cable news talk show on Fox News since 2016, with his most recent episode airing last Friday.

"We thank him for his service to the network as a host," a Fox Media spokesperson stated. Carlson’s program will be replaced by a new show titled "Fox News Tonight," which will feature various hosts.

As part of the legal proceedings, Dominion obtained group chat messages from Carlson in which he expressed strong dislike for then-President Donald Trump.

title: British Academy of Film and Television Arts announces recipients of 2023 Film Awards
content:

The German anti-war film "All Quiet on the Western Front" was the standout winner of the night, taking home seven out of the fourteen awards for which it was nominated, including Best Film, Best Director, and Best Film Not in the English Language.

Cate Blanchett won the award for Best Actress for her role in "Tár," while Austin Butler took home Best Actor for his performance in "Elvis." The Outstanding British Film award went to "The Banshees of Inisherin."

The Academy also recognized costume designer Jenny Beavan with a lifetime achievement award.

CNN described "All Quiet on the Western Front" as "the sweeping victor of the night." Producer Malte Grunert expressed his gratitude, stating, "We’ve been blessed with so many nominations and winning this is just incredible."

Mackey, another nominee, shared her pride in being nominated, calling the win “really special.”
question:

title: EU agrees €43 billion Chips Act to boost semiconductor production
content:
The European Council, representing member states, reached an agreement with the European Parliament on Tuesday regarding a new initiative aimed at enhancing the European Union's (EU) semiconductor industry and reducing dependence on Asian suppliers.

Initially proposed by the European Commission last year, the act was focused solely on subsidizing the production of cutting-edge chips. However, the scope has now expanded to include funding for facilities involved in the entire semiconductor value chain, encompassing older chips as well as research and development.

The agreement aims to secure over €43 billion from both public and private sources to support these subsidies, with the ultimate goal of quadrupling production capacity and increasing the EU's share of the semiconductor market to 20% by 2030.

The Swedish presidency of the Council of the European Union stated, "The Chips Act will enhance the European semiconductor ecosystem and play a crucial role in boosting the EU's global competitiveness."

This push for domestic chip production comes in response to the supply chain disruptions experienced in the wake of the pandemic, as well as a broader strategy to mitigate vulnerability to global shocks—especially following the invasion of Ukraine, which prompted member states to reduce their reliance on Russian gas.

In a statement released after the agreement, the internal markets commissioner noted, "This will enable us to rebalance and secure our supply chains, decreasing our collective dependency on Asia." Currently, the majority of the world’s semiconductor manufacturing and exports are dominated by firms in China and Taiwan.

This development follows the United States' commitment of approximately US$52 billion last August for microchip manufacturing, along with significant investments in research and development. Similar initiatives have also been announced by Japan and South Korea.
question:
What is the primary goal of the EU's Chips Act agreed upon by the European Council and the European Parliament?  

A) To reduce chip production costs by outsourcing to Asia  
B) To quadruple semiconductor production and increase the EU's market share to 20% by 2030  
C) To limit funding for research and design in chip manufacturing  
D) To develop a new generation of cutting-edge chips only

title: Prisoner exchange in Yemen ends after freeing over 800
content:
On April 16, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) announced the successful conclusion of a United Nations-brokered exchange involving 869 prisoners between the Aden-based government and Houthi forces amid the ongoing Yemeni civil war.

Beginning on April 14, ICRC flights transported prisoners between areas controlled by the Houthis, the government in Aden, and various Saudi Arabian cities.

According to the Associated Press, over 700 of the exchanged prisoners were affiliated with the Houthis, while the rest included Saudi and Sudanese soldiers from the Saudi-led coalition supporting the Aden government.

Among those returned to the Aden side were four journalists who were facing execution by the Houthis, as well as Major General Nasser Mansur Hadi, the former Defense Minister and brother of ex-President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi.

Additionally, the coalition independently transferred 104 Houthi prisoners of war via ICRC flights on Monday, with 96 arriving in Houthi-controlled Sana'a and eight landing in Aden.

The negotiations that took place in March near Geneva, Switzerland, paved the way for this exchange and established a timeline for further discussions in May. The United Nations-brokered Stockholm Agreement facilitated earlier conferences that resulted in similar prisoner swaps in 2020 and 2022.

Separately, Houthi representatives hosted Saudi officials for peace talks in Sana'a, which continued through Thursday.

The conflict in Yemen has been ongoing since 2014 and is increasingly viewed as a proxy struggle between Saudi Arabia and Iran, according to reports from Reuters and the Associated Press.
question:
What was the total number of prisoners exchanged between the Aden-based government and the Houthis as announced by the ICRC on April 16? 

A) 869  
B) 700  
C) 104  
D) 96

content:

title: China summons Japan's ambassador over G7's statements
content:
China summoned Japan's ambassador on Sunday to voice its protest against what it described as "hype around China-related issues." This action follows recent comments made by the Group of 7 (G7) during their meeting in Japan, which Beijing deemed as interference in its internal affairs.

Vice Foreign Minister Sun noted China's "strong dissatisfaction and resolute opposition" to the statements issued by the G7. He accused Japan, as the G7 summit chair, of collaborating with other nations to "smear and attack China," asserting that these actions grossly interfere in China's internal matters and violate fundamental principles of international law, as well as the spirit of the four political documents between China and Japan, including the 1972 Joint Communiqué.

In response, Japan's ambassador to China, Tarumi, characterized the G7's statements as "only natural," emphasizing that they address mutual interests. He suggested that if China prefers these issues to be left unmentioned, it should adopt a more positive approach.

While G7 leaders expressed concerns about China's actions, they clarified, "Our policy approaches are not designed to harm China nor do we seek to thwart China's economic progress and development... [we are not] decoupling or turning inwards." Sun highlighted that Taiwan—a self-governing island that China regards as a breakaway state—represents "the core of China's core interests" and is a "red line that must not be crossed." The G7 also criticized China for the militarization of the South China Sea and underscored the importance of "peace and stability" in maintaining global order.

The G7 accused China of employing economic coercion in ongoing disputes and expressed a desire to "reduce excessive dependencies on China" in critical supply chains.

Additionally, the G7 condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine, while Russia labeled the summit as an "incubator" of anti-Russian sentiment, which also extends to its ally, China.

On Monday, Japan’s Chief Cabinet Secretary reiterated that Japan's stance on China remains consistent, stating that the country will strive to cooperate on shared concerns while advocating for responsible conduct.

Moritz Rudolf, a scholar from Yale University's Paul Tsai China Center, commented on Beijing's swift response, indicating that tensions in the region are already quite high and are likely to escalate further.

B) Strong dissatisfaction and resolute opposition

title: Strongest tornado since 1983 strikes Los Angeles County, California
content:
On Wednesday, a tornado struck California, causing minor injuries to one individual and damaging at least 17 buildings, according to the National Weather Service (NWS). The tornado's peak winds were estimated to reach 110 miles per hour (177 kilometers per hour), classifying it as an EF-1. This marked the county's most severe tornado since 1983.

As the tornado moved into Los Angeles, it wreaked havoc on vehicles, shattered skylights, collapsed a building's roof, and uprooted a pine tree with a foot-wide trunk.

Earlier on Tuesday, an EF-0 tornado caused damage to 25 mobile homes in another part of the state, inflicting minor damage to trees in a nearby cemetery, as reported by NWS personnel.

Tornadoes are relatively rare in California, with annual estimates typically ranging from fewer than 10 to 11. Furthermore, they seldom gain significant strength or persist for extended periods.

Recent months have seen California grappling with severe weather, including flooding and at least 12 significant storms that brought flood conditions and hurricane-force winds. On Tuesday, a storm in the San Francisco area claimed at least five lives, downed over 700 trees and power lines, and led to reports of high-rise buildings shedding glass and debris.

A) 90 miles per hour

title: Canadian soldier who filmed himself sexually abusing colleague has appeal dismissed
content:

The court's ruling puts an end to McGregor's prolonged legal battles, affirming that the police's investigation of his residence in the United States was reasonable under Charter standards.

He was subsequently sentenced by a military judge in British Columbia to three years in prison and an additional twenty years on the sex offender registry, subsequently being 'dishonorably discharged' from the Armed Forces.

Following last Friday's decision, McGregor's sentence remains in effect, and upon his release, he will be prohibited from future employment with the Canadian government.

From August 2015 to March 2017, McGregor served with the Canadian Defence Liaison Staff in Washington, D.C., which granted him diplomatic immunity.

In January 2017, another member of the Canadian Armed Forces discovered two audio recording devices in her home and suspected McGregor's involvement. She reported the incident to her superior officer, prompting an investigation. The Embassy agreed to waive McGregor's diplomatic immunity at the request of the Canadian Forces National Investigation Service (CFNIS).

Forensic analysis uncovered video evidence of McGregor groping an unconscious woman in Victoria, as well as recordings of a woman using the restroom and a video featuring cartoon characters depicted in sexual acts. The latter charge of child pornography was eventually dropped.

The woman depicted in the video later testified in court that she believed the recording was made after she invited McGregor over for drinks and video games. She recalled blacking out and awakening to find him inappropriately touching her.

title: 'Let's finish this job': US President Joe Biden announces 2024 reelection bid
content:
On Tuesday, President Joe Biden formally announced his candidacy for reelection in 2024, marking exactly four years since he launched his 2020 campaign. In a three-minute launch video, Biden emphasized the theme of personal freedom, stating, "Freedom. Personal freedom is fundamental to who we are as Americans. There's nothing more important. Nothing more sacred." 

The video included images of various protests, including those advocating for abortion rights, while Biden highlighted the threats he perceives from what he described as "MAGA extremists" who seek to undermine core American freedoms. He pointed out issues such as cuts to Social Security and healthcare access for women, book bans, and voter suppression.

Using a montage that featured his first term, Vice President Kamala Harris, everyday Americans, and his Republican challengers—including former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis—Biden reiterated, "When I ran for president four years ago, I said we are in a battle for the soul of America. And we still are." He underscored the importance of defending democracy and personal freedoms, declaring, "It's time to finish the job."

At his first campaign event, Biden hailed job gains in the construction sector and energized the crowd, which chanted, "Let's Go Joe." He remarked, “We — you and I — together we're turning things around” and asserted that his administration would be "the most pro-union administration in American history."

In the Democratic primary, Biden faces challengers such as Marianne Williamson, a spiritual author, and Donald Trump, who is campaigning to regain the presidency after losing to Biden in 2020. Former President Barack Obama endorsed Biden by retweeting his launch video and expressing pride in Biden's achievements, stating, “Let's get to work!”

The Republican National Committee (RNC) chair responded with criticism, arguing that Biden is disconnected from the realities facing Americans and predicting negative consequences if he is re-elected. An RNC advertisement used AI-generated clips to depict a bleak future under a second Biden term.

Taylor Budowich, CEO of the pro-Trump organization MAGA, Inc., also issued a statement claiming America is facing a "deadly nuclear war" under Biden's leadership and criticized the president for economic challenges affecting American families.

Vice President Harris highlighted abortion rights at a rally in Washington, D.C., asserting her trust in American women, and vowed to organize against those she perceives as extremist leaders. She expressed pride in running for reelection to continue their work.

Democratic strategist Jeff Link noted that concerns about Biden's age and capabilities will be a focal point of opposition attacks, emphasizing the need for Biden to demonstrate his commitment to working-class families. With Trump's threat lingering, Link reiterated the importance of a second Biden term to prevent Trump's return.

Current polling indicates Biden's approval rating at 40%, with a significant portion of voters—70% overall and 51% among Democrats—expressing doubts about his candidacy. Many respondents cited his age as a barrier, as Biden, at 80, is the oldest president in U.S. history. While he acknowledges these concerns as "totally legitimate," he challenges critics by saying, "Watch me."

Biden's physician assessed him as "healthy, vigorous," and "fit" for office following a medical evaluation in February. Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre declined to specify whether Biden would serve a full second term but later expressed confidence that he would.

First Lady Jill Biden has shown her support for her husband's reelection bid, having said she is "all in." Following a recent trip to Ireland, Biden reaffirmed his commitment to seeking reelection.

Biden appointed his campaign manager, Mike Tyler, and deputy campaign manager Quentin Fulks, who previously managed Georgia Senator Raphael Warnock’s successful reelection campaign. The campaign also announced several co-chairs, including prominent U.S. Representatives and Senators, alongside Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer and Democratic Party donor and entertainment executive, Rita Moreno.

A) Build Back Better  
B) Make America Great Again  
C) Let's finish the job  
D) Yes We Can

title: Moldova denies Russian allegations of Ukrainian plan to attack breakaway Transnistria
content:
Moldovan officials on Thursday rejected Russia's claim that Ukraine is planning an attack on Transnistria, a breakaway region that is internationally recognized as part of Moldova. 

A Member of Parliament denounced the Russian allegations as "aggressive disinformation," while Secretary of State Valeriu Mija characterized Russia's remarks as a "psychological operation" lacking any genuine basis.

The Moldovan government, via its Telegram channel, urged citizens to remain calm and to rely on "information... from official and credible sources of the Republic of Moldova."

Earlier that day, Russia released a statement alleging that Ukraine was amassing a "significant amount of personnel and military vehicles" near the Transnistrian border in preparation for an invasion, which it claimed posed a "direct threat" to Russian troops stationed in the pro-Russian breakaway region. The Russian Ministry asserted, "The armed forces of the Russian Federation will adequately respond to the impending provocation from the Ukrainian side."

A separatist social media account claimed this week to have evidence of a Ukrainian military buildup, but it shared a photograph that only depicted a Ukrainian flag and a small number of armored vehicles.

For weeks, Moldova, which leans toward the West, has expressed concerns that Russia may be planning a coup d'état in the country. This concern intensified following Russia's retraction of a 2012 decree recognizing Moldova's sovereignty on February 22.

Transnistria declared independence from Moldova in 1990, leading to a two-year conflict. Since the end of the war, Russia has maintained around 1,500 peacekeepers in the region.
question:
What did Moldovan officials say about Russia's claims of a Ukrainian military threat to Transnistria?  

A) They confirmed the claims as true.  
B) They dismissed the claims as aggressive disinformation.

title: G20 fails to agree on joint statement on Russian invasion of Ukraine
content:
Finance chiefs from the Group of Twenty (G20) were unable to reach a consensus on a joint statement as their two-day meeting concluded on Saturday in Bengaluru, India. Both Russia and China rejected a proposed condemnation of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

India, hosting the meeting, expressed its reluctance to discuss the conflict, reaffirming its neutral stance and advocating for a diplomatic resolution. However, Western nations insisted they would not endorse any agreement that omitted a strong denunciation of Russia’s actions.

In lieu of a unified statement, India released a "chair's summary and outcome document" that encapsulated the discussions. The document noted that "most members strongly condemned the war in Ukraine," highlighting its significant toll on human suffering and its detrimental effects on the global economy, including stunted growth, rising inflation, disrupted supply chains, heightened energy and food insecurity, and increased financial stability risks.

The document also noted the presence of "other views and different assessments" regarding the conflict and sanctions. It acknowledged that while the G20 forum is not designed to address security issues, these matters can have important economic repercussions.

A footnote specified that the condemnation of the war was "agreed to by all member countries except Russia and China."

During a press conference, Indian official Ajay Seth stated that representatives from Russia and China believed their focus should remain on economic and financial matters, opposing the inclusion of Ukraine’s situation in any statement. He added, "In contrast, all other 18 countries felt the war has profound implications for the global economy."

The summit also focused on debt relief for low-income nations and the regulation of cryptocurrency. According to Reuters, countries like China, which is the world's largest bilateral creditor, are facing increased pressure to lower the debt burdens of struggling nations.

The Chinese Finance Minister reiterated Beijing’s stance that multilateral development banks, including the World Bank, should also consider accepting debt reductions to address the challenges facing these countries.

India's push for more stringent regulations on cryptocurrency received broad support from member nations. 

Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman and the International Monetary Fund’s Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva co-hosted a session on debt restructuring that involved World Bank representatives, China, India, Saudi Arabia, and G7 members. 

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen referred to the meeting as organizational, noting that no specific outcomes were produced. Georgieva highlighted the commitment to bridge differences for the benefit of impacted countries, stating, "We just finished a session in which it was clear that there is a commitment to bridge differences for the benefit of countries."

Georgieva suggested that policymakers should not rule out outright bans if regulations prove ineffective, whereas Yellen advocated for a robust regulatory framework.

Sitharaman addressed the challenges faced by countries like Ethiopia, Ghana, Sri Lanka, and Zambia, stating that "enhancing multilateral coordination by official bilateral and private creditors is essential to tackle the worsening debt situation and facilitate coordinated solutions for debt-distressed nations."

At the G20's previous meeting in November, Indonesia opted for a Leaders' Declaration instead of a communiqué due to similar disputes over the war in Ukraine.
question:
What was the primary reason for the failure to agree on a joint statement at the G20 finance chiefs meeting in Bengaluru?  

A) Disagreement on global economic policies  
B) Lack of participation from all member countries  
C) Disagreement over the need to condemn Russia's invasion of Ukraine  
D) Opposition from Western nations on climate change topics

title: UN agency reports 531 dead in Haiti, calls for international support
content:
On March 21, the United Nations (UN) called on the international community to urgently consider deploying a time-bound specialized support force to Haiti, citing escalating gang violence that has resulted in 531 deaths since the beginning of the year.

UN spokesperson Marta Hurtado highlighted that clashes between gangs are increasing in intensity and frequency, expressing her "grave concern" over the deteriorating security situation. She reported that during the first two weeks of March alone, at least 208 people were killed, 164 injured, and 101 kidnapped, with many victims reportedly targeted by snipers shooting indiscriminately at individuals in their homes or on the streets.

Hurtado also noted a troubling trend of armed gangs forcibly recruiting children, emphasizing that school closures have contributed to this loss of protection for young people. 

Additionally, she revealed that half of Haiti's population is experiencing food insecurity due to rising food prices, with over 160,000 Haitians living in precarious conditions—about a quarter of whom are in makeshift accommodations with limited access to sanitation facilities.

The Guardian reported that the idea of deploying a support force gained momentum internationally after Haitian Prime Minister Ariel Henry first requested assistance in October. The U.S. has approached Brazil to potentially lead such a force, although Brazilian Foreign Minister stated earlier this year, "I think we need to seek other solutions – I don’t know if sending troops or a peacekeeping operation is the solution."

According to Agence France-Presse (AFP), Haiti has been grappling with a political and economic crisis since the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse in July 2021, which triggered infighting among politicians. The AFP also noted that school closures have become widespread, with students and teachers caught in the crossfire and facing kidnappings.

In 2022, UN Secretary-General António Guterres called for the establishment of a "rapid action force" to assist the Haitian police. Following a visit to Haiti last month, the UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Türk, described the situation as a "living hell," revealing that 20,000 people are in a catastrophic famine-like condition. Türk urged Haitian officials to bolster the police force and implement judicial reforms to tackle the ongoing security challenges.
question:
What did the United Nations urge the international community to consider for Haiti amidst increasing gang violence?

A) Immediate economic sanctions  
B) A long-term diplomatic mission  
C) Deployment of a time-bound specialized support force  
D) Evacuation of all foreign nationals

Kacsmaryk explained in correspondence with CNN that the redaction had been approved by the appropriate authorities. He noted that the redacted entity is a private corporation based outside Texas, adding, "The Clerk's Office is aware of the entity's name, actively screens incoming cases, and I would be automatically recused from any cases involving it."

Earlier this month, Kacsmaryk suspended the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's approval of the abortion pill mifepristone, which prevented consumers from accessing the medication. The U.S. Supreme Court later issued a pause on that suspension.

These reports emerged following an investigation into Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas’ failure to disclose vacations and property transactions linked to a billionaire donor, described by the nonprofit as a conservative.

title: US National Park Service announces part of Yosemite National Park to close for days as flooding forecast
content:
On Tuesday, the National Park Service (NPS) announced that the eastern section of Yosemite National Park in California will be closed to visitors from 10:00 PM Friday through at least Wednesday due to anticipated flooding.

According to a post on Yosemite’s official Instagram account, areas such as Crane Flat and trails leading to it will remain open, as well as parts of western Yosemite Valley.

Scott Gediman, a spokesperson for Yosemite, indicated that the closure could potentially extend into June or July.

The NPS typically closes sections of the park when snowmelt is predicted to be above normal levels, warning that this is when "roads and other critical infrastructure begin to flood."

The National Weather Service forecasted temperatures this weekend will be 10° to 12°F (5.5° to 6.5°C) above average, which may accelerate the snowmelt process. 

This winter's snowfall has reached record levels, estimated at 240% above average. "I've been in Yosemite for 27 years, and I’ve never seen this much snow," Gediman remarked. Certain areas of the park received particularly heavy snowfall in February.

content:
