He expressed gratitude for his time in office, saying, "It has been an honour and privilege to serve the people of the state in my community. It is beyond what I could have ever imagined my career would amount to. WA has provided me with the opportunity of a lifetime."

In a personal message on Facebook, McGowan reflected, “I've loved the role. I've enjoyed delivering on our agenda for the benefit of our State, embracing the challenges of problem-solving, making decisions, achieving outcomes, and helping people.”

Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese praised McGowan, stating, "He has been a great Premier of his proud state, an extraordinary leader for WA Labor, and a trusted friend. In unprecedented times, Mark always held to his convictions and sought to do the right thing for his state." Albanese revealed that McGowan informed him of his decision to step down on Monday morning.

Under McGowan's leadership during the COVID-19 pandemic, his approval rating soared to 91%, and the Labor Party secured 53 of 59 lower-chamber seats in the subsequent election.

His resignation has prompted Labor to initiate the process of selecting a new leader ahead of the upcoming state election scheduled for 2025.

title: Actor Alan Cumming returns OBE for British Empire's 'toxicity'
content:
On Friday, Scottish actor and producer Alan Cumming revealed that the historical exploitation and deaths of indigenous peoples worldwide heavily influenced his decision to return the honorary title he received in 2009. 

In celebration of his 58th birthday, the two-time Tony Award winner stated that his "misgivings about being associated with the toxicity of empire" now outweigh the "great good" that the award represented for the LGBT community. Cumming was honored with the title of Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE) as part of Queen Elizabeth II's birthday honors, recognizing his work as an actor and activist for equal rights for the LGBTQ+ community.

Since becoming a U.S. citizen in 2008, Cumming has been an outspoken critic of the Defense of Marriage Act, which was later repealed, and the 'don't ask, don't tell' policy that barred openly LGBTQ+ individuals from serving in the U.S. Armed Forces. At the time of receiving the OBE, he expressed gratitude to the Queen, viewing the honor as a motivation to continue fighting for what he believes is right, and to highlight the inaction of the U.S. government on LGBTQ+ rights. "It makes me very proud to be British and galvanized as an American," he remarked.

However, following the repeal of these laws and ongoing discussions about the monarchy's role and the legacy of British colonialism after Queen Elizabeth II's death in September, Cumming felt the value of the award to the LGBTQ+ cause has diminished. He concluded that "the great good the award brought to the LGBTQ+ cause back in 2009 is now less potent than the misgivings I have about being associated with the toxicity of empire."

Cumming's decision echoes that of other celebrities who have returned their OBEs in protest of social issues. Notably, in 2020, Welsh actor Michael Sheen returned his OBE from 2009, citing the "tortured history" between Wales and the UK. Musician Paul McCartney returned his MBE in 1969 in response to the UK's involvement in the Vietnam War and its support for the U.S.

Cumming's film credits include "The Good Wife" and the "Spy Kids" trilogy, and he has received Tony Awards for producing the musical "Cabaret" (2022) and for his performance in "Cabaret" (1998). In 2019, he proudly reflected on his role in the television series "Boy Culture," the first U.S. network drama to feature a gay lead character, noting its significance in portraying same-sex marriage for the first time before a wide audience.
question:
What reason did Scottish actor Alan Cumming give for returning the Order of the British Empire he received in 2009? 

A) He was unhappy with his career choices  
B) He believed the honour's significance for the LGBT community had diminished due to historical issues  
C) He wanted to focus solely on his acting career  
D) He was pressured by his peers in the entertainment industry

title: "Energized and excited": Chris Hipkins becomes 41st Prime Minister of New Zealand
content:
On January 25, Chris Hipkins was sworn in as the new Prime Minister of New Zealand, succeeding Jacinda Ardern, who announced her unexpected resignation on January 19. 

During the swearing-in ceremony in Wellington, Governor-General Dame Cindy Kiro, representing King Charles III, officially appointed Hipkins as prime minister. Additionally, Carmel Sepuloni was appointed as the Deputy Prime Minister.

At 44 years old, Hipkins was elected unopposed as the leader of the Labour Party on January 22, and he is set to guide the party into the upcoming October elections amid economic difficulties and declining Labour popularity against a resurgent conservative opposition.

In his inaugural speech as prime minister, Hipkins, who previously spearheaded New Zealand's response to COVID-19 under Ardern's leadership, emphasized the profound responsibility of his new role. “This is the biggest privilege and responsibility of my life [...] I’m energized and excited by the challenges that lie ahead,” he stated.

Hipkins identified the cost of living as an "absolute priority" for his new administration but refrained from providing specific details just hours after taking office. Recent quarterly consumer spending figures indicated that New Zealand's inflation rate stood at 7.2%, driven primarily by rising housing and food costs.

“New Zealanders will absolutely see in the coming weeks and months that addressing the cost of living is central to our agenda [...] It is the top priority for our government, and they will see tangible evidence of our efforts,” he assured reporters, while cautioning against making premature announcements.

Sepuloni congratulated Hipkins on his victory and expressed her appreciation for her new role. Reflecting on her heritage, she noted the significance of Hipkins' leadership for their Pacific community.

On the same day, Hipkins committed to tackling what he termed a "pandemic of inflation," noting, “COVID-19 and the global pandemic created a health crisis. Now it’s created an economic one, and that’s where my government’s focus will lie.” He assured that economic concerns would not overshadow other crucial issues, such as climate change, which he described as one of the biggest challenges facing future generations.

Christopher Luxon, the Leader of the Opposition, conveyed his congratulations to Hipkins and Sepuloni via text but criticized Ardern's government as having “failed spectacularly,” suggesting that Hipkins would merely continue on the same path.

Although Hipkins previously held cabinet positions as Minister of Education and Minister of Police, he gained recognition as the 'architect' behind New Zealand's COVID-19 policies. However, according to the Associated Press, he and other Labour Party members had not achieved the same level of visibility or global recognition as Ardern, a prominent figure on the international stage for the left.

Ardern announced her resignation after nearly 15 years as a member of Parliament, stating she no longer had the energy to continue. She plans to remain an MP until April to avoid triggering a by-election before the October elections.

Elected as prime minister in a coalition government in 2017, Ardern secured a landslide victory in the 2020 election, governing during periods marked by significant challenges, including the nation’s deadliest terrorist attack, natural disasters, and the COVID-19 pandemic.

During her final event as prime minister, Ardern expressed that the people were “the joy of the job.” On the following morning, staffers and supporters gathered to bid her farewell as she exited the Parliament building.

The Prince and Princess of Wales also expressed their gratitude on social media, thanking Ardern and her family for their friendship, leadership, and support, particularly during the time of the late Queen's passing.
question:
Who succeeded Jacinda Ardern as Prime Minister of New Zealand on January 25?  

A) Damien O'Connor  
B) Chris Hipkins  
C) Carmel Sepuloni  
D) David Parker

title: Nationwide unrest continues for sixth night in France following fatal shooting of Nahel Merzouk
content:
Protests continued across France for the sixth consecutive night following the police shooting of 17-year-old Nahel Merzouk, who was of Algerian and Moroccan descent, during a traffic stop in a suburb of Paris on Tuesday. The unrest resulted in 157 arrests last night, along with injuries and damage to schools, police stations, town halls, and shops.

Tragically, a 24-year-old firefighter in Paris lost his life today while battling a blaze in a subterranean car park.

In response to the ongoing violence, President Emmanuel Macron convened a crisis meeting and ordered the deployment of additional police forces but chose not to declare a state of emergency. He urged parents to keep their children at home and called on social media platforms to remove content related to the unrest.

Macron condemned both the shooting and the ensuing violence, echoing the sentiments of Merzouk's grandmother who also called for an end to the turmoil.

The police officer involved in the shooting, who is currently under formal investigation for voluntary manslaughter and is in custody, claimed he intended to shoot Merzouk in the leg but accidentally fired a fatal shot to the chest.

The United Nations' human rights office has called on France to address any instances of racism within its law enforcement agencies.
question:
What sparked the protests in France that have continued for six consecutive nights?  

A) A new law enforcement policy  
B) The police shooting of Nahel Merzouk  
C) A public demonstration for climate change  
D) Increased taxes on citizens

title: Germany: Esslingen am Neckar hosts first Christopher Street Day
content:
On June 17, the town of Esslingen, Germany, celebrated its inaugural Christopher Street Day (CSD) to honor the LGBT community. Wikinews reporter Ash Thawley spoke with Mo Koalick, a local organizer of the event.

Police estimated that between 1,200 and 1,500 participants joined the march, proudly displaying banners with messages highlighting issues such as wage disparities; a 2017 report indicated that gay and bisexual men earn, on average, 12% less per hour (approximately €2) than their heterosexual counterparts.

In Germany and Switzerland, these celebrations are referred to as CSDs, a nod to the historical significance of Christopher Street in New York City, where the Stonewall riots occurred.

Koalick expressed a desire for greater publicity for future events and called for an expanded route for the parade, stating, "[I] would have loved to decorate the town more." Nevertheless, they conveyed satisfaction with the success of the first pride event in Esslingen, remarking, "I am very positively surprised."

Regarding social attitudes toward LGBT individuals in Germany, Koalick noted that while there are more inclusive and less inclusive spaces, Baden-Württemberg tends to be more conservative. They remarked that "older people around here are actual sweethearts that cheer us on," but that some teenagers and young adults actively demonstrate their lack of acceptance. Despite this, Koalick observed "the teeniest [tiniest] improvement," with older individuals beginning to listen, while younger people "aren't really open to learn yet."

A) 800 to 1,000  
B) 1,200 to 1,500  
C) 2,000 to 2,500  
D) 1,500 to 2,000

title: United States Coast Guard: Possible human remains in debris from imploded Titan submersible
content:
On June 28, officials announced that debris recovered from the Titan submersible, which is presumed to have imploded during a dive to the wreck of the Titanic on June 18, contained what are believed to be "presumed human remains." Remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) returned the debris to shore earlier that day.

The Titan lost contact with its support ship approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes into its descent. This prompted a search operation involving both ships and ROVs. On June 22, an ROV located debris approximately 1,600 feet from the Titanic's wreck site. U.S. Coast Guard Rear Admiral John Mauger stated that the debris was "consistent with a catastrophic implosion of the vehicle."

An acoustic detection system had identified an "anomaly consistent with an implosion or explosion" on June 18 in the area where the Titan was last known to be. An official disclosed to NPR that the Navy initially decided to continue with a search and rescue mission, making every effort to save the lives on board. During the search, crews reported sounds at 30-minute intervals; however, Carl Hartsfield from the U.S. Coast Guard indicated that some claimed to hear "banging noises," but Mauger clarified that "[t]here doesn't appear to be any connection between the noises" and the missing submersible.

Given the extreme pressure at the depth where the Titan was operating, an implosion would have resulted in instant fatalities for the five individuals on board: OceanGate CEO Stockton Rush, Pakistani-born British executive Shahzada Dawood and his 19-year-old son Suleman, British businessman Hamish Harding, and French explorer Paul-Henry Nargeolet.
question:
What did the debris recovered from the Titan submersible, presumed to have imploded during its dive, contain according to the announcement on June 28?  

A) Equipment from the dive  
B) Documents from the support ship  
C) Presumed human remains  
D) Personal belongings of the crew

title: European Space Agency's Euclid telescope launches from Florida, US
content:
Yesterday, a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket successfully launched at 11:12 AM (1512 UTC) from Florida, carrying the European Space Agency's (ESA) Euclid spacecraft. Euclid is designed to investigate dark matter and dark energy in the universe.

With a cost of €1.4 billion, Euclid will take approximately one month to reach its destination at the second Lagrange point (L2) between the Earth and the Sun. This position provides a stable orbit for observing about one-third of the sky beyond the Milky Way over a span of six years.

NASA contributed to the mission by designing and building Euclid's Near Infrared Spectrometer and Camera, as well as the Roman Space Telescope, which is tentatively scheduled for launch in May 2027. The two missions are expected to complement each other, with NASA's senior research scientist noting that "Euclid and Roman will add up to much more than the sum of their parts. Combining their observations will give astronomers a better understanding of what's actually happening in the universe."

Originally, Euclid was slated for launch from French Guiana on a Russian Soyuz rocket in March 2023, but plans were altered following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

B) To study dark matter and dark energy  
C) To transport astronauts to the International Space Station

title: UK sells £4 billion of government debt at highest yield since 2007
content:
The United Kingdom's Debt Management Office (DMO) issued £4 billion in government debt on Wednesday, with an average annual yield of 5.668%. This marks the highest yield since June 2007.

In the UK, the DMO issues gilts (government securities), which serve as a means to finance government spending that exceeds revenue from taxes.

Despite robust demand, with bids for the gilts totaling over £11 billion, yields rose to a fifteen-year high. Reports indicate that traders are anticipating further interest rate hikes from the Bank of England (BoE) due to ongoing high inflation devaluing returns.

On June 22, the BoE raised its benchmark interest rate for the thirteenth consecutive time, increasing it from 4.5% to 5%. This move followed "significant upside news in recent data indicating more persistence in inflationary pressures."

HSBC asset strategist Joseph Little stated to Reuters that the BoE may increase its main interest rate to as high as 6%, as "[i]nflation pressures show more persistency and more momentum than in other Western economies, placing the Bank in a difficult position." Furthermore, Reuters reported that investors expect rates to rise to approximately 6.25% by December before easing.

The impact of rising interest rates is evident; gilts maturing in October 2025 sold for an average yield of 4.874% last month, compared to 3.634% in January. Nevertheless, bond specialists informed Reuters last week that these gilts are among the "cheapest bonds available in the UK market."

UK inflation remained steady at 8.7% in May, defying forecasts, while core inflation, which excludes volatile items like food and energy, rose to 7.1% from 6.8% in April—a level not seen since 1992. Consequently, the BoE adjusted its projection for year-end inflation to around 5%, up from an earlier estimate of 4%.

In June 2007, the UK sold £2.5 billion worth of five-year gilts with an average yield of 5.790%.

As of 08:17 (0717 UTC) Thursday, the yield on two-year gilts stands at 5.429%, while the yield on ten-year gilts was reported at 4.548% at 08:19.
question:

A) 4.874%  
B) 5.429%  
C) 5.668%  
D) 3.634%

title: Heatwaves surge worldwide as researchers' analysis indicates global temperatures reaching new highs
content:
Last week, the world witnessed three of the hottest days on record, according to scientists using the Climate Reanalyzer program. The heat peaked on July 6, when the average global temperature reportedly hit a groundbreaking high.

The Climate Reanalyzer designated these days as surpassing the previous record, which was tied by days in July 2022 and August 2016. Researchers attributed this extreme heat to heatwaves affecting the United States, Canada, and Europe, along with a climatic phenomenon related to high temperatures in the Pacific Ocean.

The program utilizes data compiled by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the University of Maine since 1979, focusing on average global temperatures measured two meters above the Earth’s surface. Scientists have expressed confidence that these average temperature readings are the highest since the onset of instrumental measurements in the 1850s.

Additionally, it was reported last month that June was the warmest on record. The extreme temperatures during that month strained infrastructure and public health services, with residents across Europe and China, as well as approximately 120 million people in the U.S., facing heat advisories at various times.

Reports indicate that climate change has intensified this heatwave, as rising global temperatures contribute to increasing the frequency and severity of such extreme weather events, warning that future heatwaves may exceed this one in both intensity and duration.

B) La Niña

title: Australia: Victoria Cross recipient Ben Roberts-Smith loses war crimes defamation case against media outlets
content:
On June 1, a judge concluded a defamation case involving Australia's most decorated living veteran, former Corporal Ben Roberts-Smith of the SAS, ruling in favor of The Sydney Morning Herald and other defendants.

In 2018, the defendants alleged that Roberts-Smith had committed war crimes in Afghanistan, claims he argued cost him lucrative speaking engagements worth hundreds of thousands of dollars. The judge found evidence that supported certain accusations against Roberts-Smith, including that he killed, or permitted the killings of, unarmed individuals, which aligned with the civil standard of proof.

Nick McKenzie, an investigative journalist involved in uncovering the allegations against Roberts-Smith, stated, "Today is a day of justice for the courageous members of the SAS who bravely exposed Ben Roberts-Smith for who he truly is: a war criminal, a bully, and a liar." He added that it also represents a measure of justice for the Afghan victims of Roberts-Smith's actions.

During the hearing, Roberts-Smith was on the Indonesian island of Bali, where his presence was not mandatory. The Guardian speculated that he may be liable to pay the defendants millions of Australian dollars, noting that both parties have spent around AU$35 million on the trial. The report also estimated that his employer had lent him AU$2 million to finance the case, secured against his Victoria Cross.

The defendants accused Roberts-Smith of various war crimes, including kicking a captured civilian off a cliff in Darwan in 2012 and ordering a subordinate to execute him, machine-gunning a Taliban prisoner in 2009, and instructing troops to kill two civilians to commemorate their first combat kill. Additionally, a witness recounted that Roberts-Smith had claimed to have shot an Afghan teenager in the head, describing the boy as "shaking like a leaf" with fear.

A prosecution of Roberts-Smith would require "proof beyond a reasonable doubt." 

Prior to the allegations, many Australians regarded Roberts-Smith as a national hero. He was awarded the Victoria Cross, Australia's highest military honor, in 2011 and met Queen Elizabeth II shortly afterward, remarking to the press, "It is very humbling." In 2018, then-Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull referred to him as a "great Australian hero."

title: Wikinews interviews Steven Meserve, founder of Loving Cats Worldwide, ahead of 2023 Birmingham Cat Extravaganza show
content:
**Interview Highlights: Steven Meserve of Loving Cats Worldwide**

On Tuesday, Ash Thawley of Wikinews interviewed Steven Meserve, the founder of Loving Cats Worldwide (LCWW), in anticipation of their upcoming Cat Extravaganza in Birmingham, UK, scheduled for December 2-3.

LCWW aims to "increase the visibility of all cats," providing education on responsible cat ownership while addressing the pressing issue of cat rescue. The organization also advocates for the preservation of cat breeds and ethical breeding practices, all while organizing interactive Cat Extravaganzas across various cities. This year, additional events are planned in Liverpool, Scotland, Peru, the United States, Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Colombia.

By April, videos featuring past events garnered millions of views online.

**What inspired you to establish LCWW?**

"Loving Cats Worldwide was founded to raise awareness for all cats. Dogs have enjoyed the limelight for too long, and it's time for cats to shine. There is a lack of education regarding cat ownership and an urgent need to address the overwhelming numbers of cats in rescue situations. I started LCWW in 2015 to make a significant impact and bring cats to the global stage."

**Your website mentions a commitment to 'ethical breeding.' How do you define that?**

"An ethical breeder must conduct comprehensive genetic and health testing, maintain excellent living conditions for their cats, and thoroughly research their breed. Prospective cat owners should also be diligent when purchasing kittens. Ethical breeders ensure their kittens are vaccinated, dewormed, and treated for common health issues before going to their new homes, typically at a minimum age of 13 weeks."

**What measures does LCWW take to support ethical breeding?**

"We have established strict guidelines for breeders wishing to be associated with LCWW. On our website, you can find the 'LCWW Cats and Kittens' database featuring ethical breeders. Our organization serves as a hub of information, creating informative content and raising awareness across our digital platforms. We are always available for advice via email or social media."

**How do you view the "adopt, don't shop" philosophy?**

"Adopt Don't Shop and the importance of pedigree cats are often seen as opposing viewpoints. However, I believe we're pioneering a bridge between the two. There is value in both approaches, and collaborating with rescue and adoption centers is the most effective way to achieve meaningful change. We have an informative video on our stance regarding this on our YouTube channel."

**What goals does your organization have for the Cat Extravaganzas?**

"Our Cat Extravaganza and Rescue Awareness Events allow visitors to support local charities and rescues, experience an International Cat Competition, and enjoy the beauty of various cat breeds. Attendees can learn more about cats, engage in shopping, and even bring home gifts for their pets. Each event helps foster a deeper appreciation for these incredible animals while advancing our mission to raise global visibility for all cats."

**What led you to choose the National Exhibition Centre for your Birmingham event?**

"We are thrilled to host the Birmingham Cat Extravaganza at the NEC this December. It’s one of the premier venues in the UK, known for its incredible facilities, and we’re excited to bring a focus on cats to a place that usually showcases other events."

**What is the future direction for LCWW?**

"We aim to continually support local rescues, charities, and ethical breeders. Our goal is to expand the Meserve foundation’s mission through education and initiatives, ultimately reducing the number of cats in need and ensuring a brighter future for all felines."
question:
What is the primary goal of Loving Cats Worldwide as stated by its founder Steven Meserve?  
  
A) To promote dog adoption over cat adoption  
B) To increase the visibility of all cats and educate the public about cat ownership  
C) To exclusively support ethical breeders  
D) To host cat competitions only in the UK

title: Former US President Donald Trump pleads not guilty over alleged attempts to 'subvert' 2020 presidential election results
content:
**Revised News Article:**

On Thursday, former U.S. President Donald Trump pleaded not guilty in the District of Columbia to four felony charges related to the alleged "pursuit of unlawful means to discount legitimate votes and subvert" the outcome of the 2020 presidential election, which resulted in his defeat by current President Joe Biden. The charges stem from events connected to the Capitol attack by Trump supporters on January 6, 2021.

Magistrate Judge Tanya Chutkan, who will preside over the case, indicated during the arraignment that a trial could be scheduled at a hearing on August 28. Prosecutors and Trump's legal team have been instructed to propose their preferred trial timelines by that date. Judge Chutkan also expressed a willingness to allow Trump to skip the upcoming hearing if necessary.

Lead prosecutor Thomas Windom emphasized the need for a timely trial, stating, "This case will benefit from normal order, including a speedy trial." In contrast, Trump's defense attorney argued that his team requires more time to review the evidence provided by the government, describing the notion of a quick trial as "somewhat absurd": "These are weighty issues. Obviously, the U.S. has had three and a half years to investigate this matter."

Defense counsel requested adequate time to prepare for a fair trial, with one attorney stating: "We need the opportunity to defend our client properly." Judge Chutkan assured all parties of a fair process throughout the proceedings.

During the arraignment, Judge Chutkan reminded Trump of the conditions of his release, including a prohibition against discussing the case with witnesses without legal representation present. She warned that noncompliance could result in an arrest warrant.

Three law enforcement officers present during the Capitol attack attended the arraignment to observe the proceedings, including former Capitol Police officer Aquilino Gonell, who suffered injuries during the violence. Gonell remarked to the Associated Press, "It's the same court where hundreds of rioters have been sentenced... It's the same court where former President Trump is being arraigned for his alleged involvement before, during, and after the siege."

Among the attendees were Judge Randy Moss and other judges who have previously criticized Trump during sentences related to the Capitol attack. Providing legal representation for Trump were attorneys John Lauro and Todd Blanche, who also represent him in other ongoing cases. They have argued that Special Counsel Jack Smith’s charges infringe upon Trump’s freedom of speech.

After his arraignment, Trump stood in the rain and declared it a "very sad day for America." He claimed that the charges are a form of persecution against him because he is leading in the Republican primary and ahead of Biden in the polls. Trump stated: "If you can't beat 'em, you persecute 'em or you prosecute 'em. We can't let this happen in America." He continues to assert his innocence.

At a campaign stop in Iowa, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, a Republican candidate for the 2024 election, was asked whether he believed the 2020 election was "stolen." He replied, "I've said many times the election is what it is... All those theories that were put out did not prove to be true."

Following Trump's threatening post on social media earlier that day—stating "IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!"—prosecutors requested a protective order to prevent him from disclosing sensitive evidence, claiming it might intimidate witnesses. Trump’s attorneys subsequently submitted a response agreeing that some documents should remain confidential but argued against an overly broad confidentiality order, citing First Amendment protections.

On Sunday, Trump took to Truth Social to express his belief that he cannot receive a fair trial under the currently assigned judge, suggesting an immediate recusal and a change of venue away from D.C. He claimed that West Virginia would be a more "politically unbiased" location.

On August 1, a federal grand jury indicted Trump on several charges, including conspiracy to defraud the United States and obstruction of an official proceeding, alleging that he sought to undermine the certification of the election results by Congress.

This indictment followed another in New York City relating to state-level charges concerning hush money payments, marking the first indictment of a former U.S. president, as well as an additional federal indictment in Miami for allegedly retaining classified documents. Trump is also under investigation in Georgia for attempts to influence that state’s election results.

Unlike impeachment, a conviction unrelated to an insurrection would not legally impede Trump’s campaign. The indictment details that Trump exhausted his legal options regarding the election results and participated in a conspiracy to falsely assert he won the election. It states that despite being informed of the truth by Vice President Mike Pence and other advisors, Trump "widely disseminated" false claims, aiming to instill distrust in the election process.

The indictment also accuses Trump of pressuring state officials to change election results and of attempting to persuade Pence to prevent Congress from certifying the electoral votes. Additionally, Trump and his associates allegedly organized "fraudulent electors" to submit votes for him.

Prosecutor Jack Smith described the situation as "an unprecedented assault on the seat of American democracy," attributing the chaos on January 6, 2021, to lies propagated by Trump. A bipartisan investigation by the U.S. House Select Committee, which looked into the events leading to the Capitol attack, recommended charges against Trump for aiding an insurrection and obstructing official proceedings. Judge Chutkan previously ruled that Trump's presidential records should be made available to the committee, against his wishes, and these records were mentioned in the grand jury's indictment.

Hours before his arraignment, Trump labeled Judge Chutkan as "unfair" on social media.
question:
What charges did former US President Donald Trump plead not guilty to during his arraignment in Washington D.C.?

A) Tax evasion and money laundering  
B) Felony charges related to election interference  
C) Fraudulent business practices  
D) Assault and battery

title: US Supreme Court blocks stay on federal regulation on privately made firearms
content:
On Tuesday, the U.S. Supreme Court voted 5-4 to temporarily reinstate a 2022 regulation on "ghost guns," also known as privately made firearms (PMFs). The ruling halted a lower court's decision that had suspended the regulation during the appeal process by President Joe Biden's administration.

In June, U.S. District Judge of Texas ruled that the administration lacked the authority to redefine ghost gun parts and kits as firearms, arguing that, according to Congress, a firearm cannot solely consist of "weapon parts, or aggregations of weapon parts," regardless of the assembly potential into a functional weapon.

The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) implemented the final rule 2021R-05F, known as the "Frame or Receiver" rule. This regulation requires that "easy-to-build" gun kits be marked with serial numbers and mandates background checks for buyers of these kits, which contain all necessary components to assemble a firearm. Previously, such kits were available without these requirements. The ATF's aim with the Frame or Receiver rule was to enhance "proper marking, recordkeeping, and traceability" of firearms.

John Feinblatt, president of Everytown, expressed optimism in a statement, saying, "Americans across the country will be safer thanks to the Supreme Court's decision today to keep ATF's life-saving ghost guns rule in effect while the appeals process unfolds."

Conversely, Cody J. Wisniewski, representing one of the plaintiffs, the Firearms Policy Coalition, expressed disappointment, stating, "We're deeply disappointed that the Court pressed pause on our defeat of ATF's rule that effectively redefines 'firearm' and 'ghost gun' under federal law."

Under existing laws, regulations did not address privately made firearms intended for personal and lawful use, making their creation legal as long as the individual was permitted to own a firearm. For certain weapons, the ATF mandated a registration process similar to purchasing a firearm from a licensed dealer.

The ATF has reported an increase in the number of unserialized firearms found in connection to criminal investigations, attributing this rise to advancements in technology and the accessibility of firearm manufacturing instructions. This surge prompted the agency to develop the "Frame or Receiver" rule.
question:
What was the primary purpose of the ATF's "Frame or Receiver" rule established in 2021?  

A) To allow for unregulated gun sales between individuals.  
B) To mandate serial numbers and background checks for ghost gun kits.  
C) To increase the production of ghost guns without oversight.  
D) To eliminate the need for licenses when selling firearms.

title: US: Writers, entertainment producers' groups meet two months into writers' strike; writers' says 'no agreement'
content:

WGA representatives informed union members in a memo that no agreement had been reached, as the AMPTP indicated that it needed to consult with its member studios.

The AMPTP chose not to provide any comments on the meeting.

The WGA memo further indicated that AMPTP's Lombardini expressed a willingness to increase some TV minimums specific to writers and to discuss artificial intelligence, but she was not open to negotiations on the preservation of certain conditions or success-based compensation.

The AMPTP has dismissed the WGA's proposals related to writers' room staffing as a form of "hiring quota."

The WGA noted that Lombardini did not indicate any willingness to address issues concerning screenwriters, Appendix A matters, or other outstanding proposals.

The memo also stated that if an agreement is reached between the WGA and AMPTP, the WGA plans to maintain the strike until the actors' union resolves its own disputes.

Following the meeting, the WGA accused the AMPTP of leaking details to industry magazines despite initially stating that such information should be kept confidential. According to reports, AMPTP's President Carol Lombardini was initially resistant to moving forward with discussions; however, studio officials—including Sony Pictures CEO—urged her to continue the talks.

title: Federal grand jury indicts former US President Donald Trump in classified documents inquiry
content:
A federal grand jury in Miami, Florida, indicted former U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday on 37 counts, marking the first federal indictment of a former president. The charges include willfully retaining national defense secrets, conspiracy to obstruct justice, concealing documents in a federal investigation, and making false statements.

Trump's attorney, Jim Trusty, stated that Trump plans to attend a court hearing scheduled for Tuesday following a summons.

According to the indictment, Trump and his staff transported hundreds of classified documents from the White House to his residence in Mar-a-Lago, Florida, in January 2021 as his presidency concluded. Beginning in May 2021, the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) sought the return of these documents. In January 2022, Trump’s team provided NARA with 197 documents, some marked as "CONFIDENTIAL" and others as "TOP SECRET." This prompted NARA to request an investigation from the Department of Justice (DoJ) the following month.

The indictment alleges that in December 2021, Trump's co-defendant, \(Name\), discovered classified documents—including one marked "SECRET//REL TO USA, FVEY," which signifies it should only be shared with U.S. allies—scattered on the floor of a storage closet at Mar-a-Lago.

Furthermore, the indictment claims Trump stored documents at his Bedminster, New Jersey property, including a partial transcript of a conversation in which he told an interviewer, a publisher, and two aides that he was sharing classified information not officially declassified prior to leaving office, contradicting his previous claims regarding all documents housed at Mar-a-Lago.

The indictment also implicated a Trump attorney in making false statements to the FBI and DoJ last June, asserting that she and a colleague were providing all required classified documents. Meanwhile, it is alleged that Trump directed staffer \(\text{Name}\) to relocate documents while the attorney was searching for records to comply with a May 2022 subpoena from the grand jury. The FBI executed a search warrant at Mar-a-Lago in August, reportedly seizing 102 documents marked as classified, based on surveillance footage showing \(\text{Name}\) moving the documents.

Special Counsel \(\text{Name}\) filed the charges in the Southern District of Florida, following an investigation appointed by U.S. Attorney General \(\text{Name}\) into Trump’s handling of classified materials.
question:

A) Tax evasion, money laundering, conspiracy to commit fraud, obstruction of justice  
B) Willfully retaining national defense secrets, conspiracy to obstruct justice, concealing a document in a federal investigation, false statements  
C) Election interference, campaign finance violations, conspiracy against the United States, abuse of power  
D) Treason, espionage, bribery, racketeering

title: Tens of thousands march in 25th Tel Aviv Pride parade
content:
Tens of thousands, with estimates reaching 150,000, gathered in Tel Aviv on Thursday for the 25th annual Pride Parade, the largest LGBT event in the Middle East.

The Associated Press reported a festive atmosphere at the parade, highlighting a stark contrast to a previous event on June 1, where over 2,000 police officers were deployed for security. Attendees from near and far joined the celebration in droves.

Israeli participant Ohad Huri, who sported a rainbow-colored beard, expressed his commitment to advocating for minority rights, stating, "I'm a minority. I want to save my rights. I want to fight for the rights of other minorities. I want equality. That's about it."

In an interview with The Times of Israel, Omer Elad, head of a local transgender group, emphasized the importance of the parade in light of the current political climate in Israel. He pointed out that National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir has previously expressed opposition to the festival, while a deputy minister questioned its legality, and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich has openly identified as a "proud homophobe."

Despite these challenges, the Associated Press noted that Israel is relatively progressive regarding LGBT rights compared to other countries in the Middle East.
question:
What was the estimated number of participants in the yearly LGBT parade held in Tel Aviv, Israel?  

A) 50,000  
B) 100,000  
C) 150,000  
D) 200,000

title: Italy: Former PM Silvio Berlusconi dies at age 86
content:
Silvio Berlusconi, the former Prime Minister of Italy, passed away yesterday in Milan at the age of 86.

Berlusconi's health had been deteriorating, with reports from his doctor in April indicating that he had been unwell for some time prior to his admission to intensive care due to a lung infection.

He holds the distinction of being Italy's longest-serving Prime Minister in the post-World War II era, serving across three non-consecutive terms from 1994 to 2011. The political party he founded has been an integral part of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's government since October.

Berlusconi's career was marked by numerous controversies, including allegations of hosting "bunga bunga" parties involving underage girls at his villas. While he was acquitted of those charges and related witness bribery charges, he was convicted of tax fraud, engaging in sexual activities with a minor prostitute, and abusing his power in an attempt to have police release the detained prostitute.

British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's spokesperson remarked, "Silvio Berlusconi made a significant impact on Italian politics over several decades, and our thoughts are with the Italian people and his family during this time."

In honor of Berlusconi, a national day of mourning has been scheduled for Wednesday.
question:
What was Silvio Berlusconi's age at the time of his death?  
A) 82  
B) 84  
C) 86  
D) 90

title: England: Parts of Birmingham area flood; music festival evacuates
content:
Birmingham, England experienced significant flooding on Saturday due to heavy rainfall, prompting a yellow weather warning for the region. The Mostly Jazz Funk and Soul Festival was forced to evacuate, with organizers describing the conditions as "biblical."

In a statement, the festival team expressed gratitude to attendees: "Thank you to everyone for your patience and cooperation. We're relieved that everyone made it out safely, and we are very appreciative of our staff for managing a safe evacuation."

Additionally, a planned job fair, titled "Big Boost," which was expected to attract 1,000 participants, had to be rescheduled after flooding affected its host venue at a local stadium.

The local social media page imjustbrum shared a video showing flooded streets across Birmingham, with reports of water seeping through roofs in various locations, including two shopping centers. The post cheekily remarked, "Birmingham really does have more canals than Venice!"

Residents reported that floodwaters invaded homes, though one local, Bradshaw, commented that the "treacherous conditions" hadn't stopped the "plague of speeding down Spring Lane."

Major roads, including Alum Rock Road and Highgate Road, were also submerged. Flooding caused the A45 to be closed, according to reports.

The Met Office has forecasted rain for Sunday between 3 PM and 7 PM, with the possibility of heavy and thundery showers later in the afternoon. "Expect a fine start with some sunny spells, though it may be hazy at times. While it won't feel as muggy, it will still be warm during sunny intervals, with a maximum temperature of 24°C (75°F)," a spokesperson said.

The Mostly Jazz Funk and Soul Festival announced another evacuation on Sunday through a tweet: "This is a safety announcement. We have been tracking a storm; with lightning strikes nearby, it is not safe to remain in the park, even under cover. You must evacuate now using the nearest exit. We recommend seeking shelter in the cafes and pubs of Moseley Village until the storm passes. Once it’s safe, you are welcome to return as you please for the rest of the day. Please check our social media for updates. Stay safe, MJFS."
question:
What event was evacuated due to severe weather conditions in Birmingham, England?  

A) A job fair  
B) A concert  
C) The Mostly Jazz Funk and Soul Festival  
D) A city council meeting

title: Twitter threatens to sue Meta over rival app Threads
content:
On Wednesday, Alex Spiro, an attorney representing Twitter, sent a letter to CEO Mark Zuckerberg, accusing Meta of stealing trade secrets to develop its new app, Threads, which he claims is a "copycat" of Twitter.

The letter accused Meta of "systemic, willful, and unlawful misappropriation of Twitter’s trade secrets and other confidential information." It specifically mentioned that Meta has hired "dozens" of former Twitter employees who still have access to this sensitive information. Spiro demanded that Meta take immediate action to stop utilizing any of Twitter's trade secrets.

In response to the letter, Twitter owner Elon Musk, who purchased the platform for $44 billion last year, tweeted, "Competition is fine; cheating is not."

Threads features a user interface similar to Twitter's, allowing users to create 500-character posts, reply to others, repost, and quote posts. In a post on Threads, Zuckerberg expressed optimism about the app's future, stating, "It'll take some time, but I think there should be a public conversations app with over 1 billion people on it. Twitter has had the opportunity to do this but hasn't nailed it. Hopefully, we will."

Within just two days of its launch in over 100 countries, Threads gained over 70 million users, according to Meta's head of communications. However, the app has yet to be released in the European Union, reportedly due to Meta's concerns regarding regulatory restrictions imposed by the bloc last year.
question:
What allegation did Twitter's attorney, Alex Spiro, make against Meta regarding the Threads app?  

A) Meta failed to innovate in social media.  
B) Meta misappropriated Twitter's trade secrets.  
C) Meta's app was a complete failure.  
D) Meta did not hire enough employees.

title: US: Tulsa residents approve $814 million infrastructure package
content:
On Tuesday, voters in Tulsa, Oklahoma, approved an $814 million infrastructure improvement package known as "Improve Our Tulsa 3." The measure received over 60% of the votes cast, surpassing the threshold needed for approval.

Tulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum advocated for the initiative, emphasizing the need for improved maintenance of city facilities. "We've allowed our infrastructure to fall behind," he stated. "Earlier this year, my colleagues on the council and I toured critical city facilities, and what we saw was, frankly, embarrassing."

However, City Councilor Grant Miller raised concerns about the approval process, arguing that the council had insufficient time to review the proposed projects.

The approved measure will maintain the city's sales tax rate at 3.65%, reallocating some revenue to fund improvements. This includes the issuance of $42 million in new bonds alongside existing bonds.

The funding will support various projects, including $95 million for housing developments, $93.8 million for previously approved street projects, $46 million for widening streets, $58.5 million for upgrading fire department vehicles, $47.5 million for a new facility for police and municipal courts, and $79.7 million for enhancements to Tulsa's Performing Arts Center.
question:
What is the total amount approved by voters in Tulsa for the infrastructure improvement package?  

A) $814 million  
B) $95 million  
C) $46 million  
D) $42 million

title: U.S. tennis player Coco Gauff wins U.S. Open women's singles tournament
content:
U.S. tennis player Coco Gauff triumphed over Belarusian Aryna Sabalenka in the U.S. Open final on Saturday in New York City. Gauff secured her first Grand Slam title in a thrilling three-set match, winning with scores of 2–6, 6–3, and 6–2.

Following her victory, a visibly emotional Gauff remarked, "I feel like I'm a little bit in shock in this moment." She added, "I'm just thankful for this moment; I don't have any words for it, to be honest."

At just 19 years old, Gauff is the first U.S. teenager to reach the U.S. Open women’s final since Serena Williams, who was also 19 when she played against her older sister Venus in 2001. Gauff is the first American to win the tournament since Venus Williams in 1999.

Earlier in the tournament, Gauff defeated Latvian player Jūlija Gabuza in the quarterfinals with a commanding score of 6–0 and 6–2, earning her a spot in the semifinals against Czech player Markéta Vondroušová. Gauff continued her strong performance on Thursday, defeating Muchová in straight sets to secure her place in the final.

Sabalenka, 25, who reached the U.S. Open semifinals in both 2021 and 2022, claimed her first career Grand Slam title earlier this year at the Australian Open. After the final, she expressed pride in managing her emotions during the match, stating, "I'm most proud that I was able to handle my emotions pretty well and focus on myself, not on the ranking." She reflected on her performance, saying, "Today on the court, I was overthinking and missing balls I shouldn't be missing."
question:
Who did U.S. tennis player Coco Gauff defeat to win her first trophy at the U.S. Open final?

A) Aryna Sabalenka  
B) Elina Svitolina  
C) Markéta Vondroušová  
D) Coco Gauff

title: England: West Midlands region floods amid heavy rain, high winds
content:
On Monday, severe storms impacted the region of England, prompting the Met Office to issue an "amber" weather warning. The forecast indicated high winds affecting areas from Staffordshire to Shropshire.

In one incident, a row of flats suffered significant flooding, with a resident telling the BBC that water poured in through "people's windows, doors, and the brickwork." Chris Hopkins, another resident, recounted that his family had just returned home in August after previous flooding, while another tenant lamented that "we can't live in this situation" of ongoing inundation. Penn Road in the city also experienced flooding, with an observer remarking to the Express & Star, "I've never seen Penn Road like this; it's like a river."

Traffic disruptions ensued as two of the three northbound lanes on the motorway between junctions J2 and J3 were flooded, resulting in a traffic jam stretching a mile long. Earlier, a fallen tree had briefly blocked access at junction J2. Additionally, Wolverhampton Road in Oldbury was also submerged.

In another incident, a fallen tree caused a shutdown on Wolverhampton Road East.

Rail service disruptions were reported, with trains running "at reduced speed" on routes affected by flooding, according to tweets from the rail operator.

By yesterday, the Met Office had issued a "yellow" thunderstorm warning for Sunday for most of England and parts of Wales. The warning highlighted the risk of sudden flooding, which could create hazardous driving conditions and potential road closures, as well as rapid flooding of homes and businesses.
question:

A) Green  
B) Amber  
C) Yellow  
D) Red

title: Wikinews interviews Tom Pashby, leader of campaign group Include Mx
content:
Wikinews reporter Ash Thawley interviewed Tom Pashby, head of the advocacy group Include Mx, on June 10. The group has been promoting the option for customers to select the gender-neutral honorific "Mx" on forms, which is particularly significant for non-binary individuals and those who prefer not to disclose their gender, like Pashby.

Pashby initiated a petition in July urging a major retailer to include "Mx" as a title option, highlighting the company's use of gender-neutral branding in their logo. The petition has attracted nearly 13,000 signatures. Earlier this month, the parent company of Argos expressed its commitment to inclusivity, stating to The Retail Bulletin that they are working to accommodate customer feedback.

**What is Include Mx?**
Include Mx is a micro-campaign that celebrates organizations that incorporate the gender-neutral title "Mx" on their forms and encourages others to follow suit.

**What inspired the creation of Include Mx? Was there a specific event that sparked it?**
Yes, it originated during the early days of the pandemic when reliance on online shopping increased. I encountered difficulties while purchasing household items from Argos. The retailer required customers to select a title at checkout but did not offer "Mx" as an option, which was frustrating as a non-binary person. Rather than simply complaining on social media, I decided to invest time into campaigning for major brands like Argos to introduce "Mx."

**How frequently do companies respond positively to the campaign? Have you experienced any negative responses?**
Responses are about evenly split; around 50% of companies say they will "look into it." Unfortunately, Argos has reportedly been "looking into it" since around 2011. No companies have responded in an overtly negative manner.

**Which company has shown the best response to adding the "Mx" title?**
Both Tesco and Sainsbury’s had the most positive reactions to the campaign, promptly adding "Mx" upon my request and publicly supporting the initiative.

**Have you encountered any personal backlash related to the campaign?**
I'm pleasantly surprised that I haven't faced much backlash concerning Include Mx itself. While I have received hate and transphobia from other campaigns, the only significant negative reaction linked to Include Mx was a critical article by a media outlet that seemed unaware of the campaign, as they did not research "Mx."

**What do you envision for the future of Include Mx?**
Ideally, I hope that Include Mx will become obsolete as companies either adopt "Mx" as a standard option or eliminate title fields altogether.
question:
What is the purpose of the Include Mx campaign?

A) To pressure companies to stop using honorifics  
B) To celebrate organizations that include the gender-neutral title Mx on their forms  
C) To promote the use of traditional honorifics only  
D) To discourage online shopping

title: U.S. federal judge upholds Oregon Ballot Measure 114 gun permit requirement, magazine regulations
content:
On Friday, U.S. District Court Judge Karin Immergut upheld the constitutionality of Oregon's Measure 114 in response to four consolidated lawsuits. This measure prohibits the possession, use, production, or transfer of large capacity magazines (LCMs) that hold more than ten rounds of ammunition, with certain exceptions, and mandates that prospective gun owners obtain a permit.

The plaintiffs in the case included special interest groups, firearms retailers, gun owners, county sheriffs, and a security professional.

Judge Immergut's ruling does not impact Circuit Court Judge Robert Raschio's December 6 order, which temporarily prevents Measure 114 from being implemented. A trial regarding this issue is scheduled for September.

Immergut affirmed that the "permit-to-purchase framework," which includes a background check, safety training, and mental health evaluation, aligns with the regulations deemed constitutional by the United States Supreme Court under the Second Amendment.

She also stated that regulating LCMs, given their "uniquely dangerous propensities," is consistent with the nation's historical approach to regulating particularly hazardous weapons to safeguard public safety.

During the trial, it was noted that Mark Hanish, a former Vice President of Marketing and Sales for a firearms manufacturer, testified that the same LCMs are sold both to the military and to civilian buyers. Judge Immergut concluded that LCMs, even in civilian hands, are closely associated with military-grade weaponry.

Throughout the seven-day trial, the plaintiffs' attorneys contended that magazines are essential for the operation of firearms and thus should be protected under the Second Amendment. However, Immergut ruled that while magazines are often necessary for a firearm’s operation, LCMs do not qualify for this protection.

Oregon Attorney General Ellen Rosenblum praised Immergut's decision, stating, "Our team looks forward to ultimately prevailing in the state courts as well. Measure 114's provisions – endorsed by Oregon voters – are common sense safety measures that will save lives."

In response, the Oregon Firearms Federation criticized the ruling as "simple nonsense" and expressed confidence that it would be overturned on appeal.

Measure 114 was approved by 50.65% of Oregon voters on November 8, 2022.
question:
What did U.S. District Court Judge Immergut uphold regarding Oregon's Measure 114?

A) The measure allows for unlimited possession of large-capacity magazines.  
B) The measure requires gun owners to obtain a permit and bans LCMs over ten rounds.  
C) The measure was struck down, allowing for the immediate sale of LCMs.  
D) The measure grants gun owners unrestricted rights under the Second Amendment.

title: Mark Rutte Dutch caretaker cabinet announces election in November
content:
Following a recommendation from the Interior Minister, a general election will be held in the Netherlands on November 22, Prime Minister Mark Rutte announced Friday, just a week after his government resigned over disagreements regarding asylum policy.

As of July 1, the ruling coalition, led by Rutte's People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD), was ahead in polling for the upcoming election.

Rutte, who has served as Prime Minister for four consecutive terms, submitted his resignation on July 8. He later revealed his decision to leave politics altogether, stating it was a personal choice not influenced by the government's collapse.

The VVD, supported by the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA), has advocated for limiting the influx of refugee children into the Netherlands and proposed keeping refugee families separated for a minimum of two years, a stance opposed by the Labour Party and the GreenLeft.

In February, the CDA introduced a proposal to distinguish between temporary and permanent refugees, suggesting that temporary asylum seekers be granted protection for one to three years, with the possibility of extension if their home country remains in a state of war for over three years.

In 2022, the number of asylum applications in the Netherlands surged by a third, exceeding 46,000.
question:
When is the scheduled election in the Netherlands following the resignation of Prime Minister Rutte?  
A) November 15  
B) November 22  
C) December 1  
D) December 5

title: Georgia grand jury indicts former US President Trump, alleging 'conspiracy to unlawfully change outcome' of 2020 presidential election
content:
On Monday, a grand jury in Fulton County, Georgia, indicted 19 individuals, including former President Donald Trump, on a total of 41 counts. Trump himself faces 13 charges as part of the case, which stems from alleged attempts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election in Georgia and nationwide. The indictment claims that the defendants "refused to accept that Trump lost" and actively participated in a conspiracy to unlawfully change the election outcome in his favor.

The indictment details a "common plan and purpose" to commit multiple acts of racketeering in Fulton County and other states. Following the indictment, Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis stated that the accused have eleven days to surrender.

Trump is charged with violating the Georgia Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act, along with several other counts, including three counts of soliciting a public officer to violate their oath, conspiracy to commit impersonation of a public officer, and multiple counts related to forgery and filing false documents.

In response to the indictment, Trump declared, "I didn't tamper with the election!" His campaign described the charges as "election interference," criticizing the prosecutor's handling of the case as politically motivated. The campaign expressed that the prosecution undermines public trust and suggested it was a coordinated attack.

On Tuesday, Trump announced on his social media platform that he would present a detailed report on alleged election fraud in Georgia in a press conference scheduled for the following Monday, but later decided to forgo the event. He indicated that his legal team would instead file this evidence in formal legal documents as part of their efforts to challenge the indictment.

This indictment marks yet another legal challenge for Trump, following earlier charges in New York related to hush money payments, federal charges connected to the retention of classified documents, and accusations of trying to subvert the 2020 election results in Washington, D.C. While state-level criminal charges could not be pardoned by a sitting president, they do not carry the same implications as impeachment and conviction by Congress.

The 98-page indictment mentions an additional 30 individuals in connection with the conspiracy but does not name or charge them. It alleges that Trump and his associates, including lawyers Rudy Giuliani and John Eastman, attempted to persuade state officials to alter the certification process for the election results.

Specific allegations include Trump urging Georgia’s Governor Brian Kemp and Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger to "find" enough votes to overcome Biden's victory. The indictment also claims that Trump organized individuals to pose as legitimate electors and pressured GOP members to present unsubstantiated claims of election fraud.

One key figure in the case, former Chief of Staff Mark Meadows, is accused of attempting to gain unlawful access to a civic center in Fulton County where state officials were conducting election-related audits. The grand jury indicted him for violating RICO and soliciting a public officer to violate his oath, tied to Trump’s call with Raffensperger.

The grand jury's investigation included testimony from several notable Trump associates and officials, contributing to the evidence against those charged. Both DA Willis and Judge Robert McBurney noted that Shafer, a participant in the pro-Trump electors plan, could face significant legal repercussions as the case unfolds.
question:
Who was indicted alongside former President Donald Trump for attempting to unlawfully change the outcome of the 2020 election in Georgia?  

A) Rudy Giuliani  
B) Joe Biden  
C) Lindsey Graham  
D) Frances Watson

title: Wikinews attends Animeleague's summer 2023 Birmingham, UK Anime & Gaming Con
content:
In late August, over 4,000 attendees flocked to the Animeleague Birmingham Anime & Gaming Convention in the UK, according to organizers. Wikinews reporter Ash Thawley attended on the second day, August 27, from 11:00 AM BST (10:00 AM UTC) to 2:00 PM BST (1:00 PM UTC).

The convention's Exhibition Hall featured a variety of merchandise, including crystals, anime and video game memorabilia, and food items such as doughnuts. Notable exhibits included swords and merchandise from popular franchises, while well-known artists made appearances in the Hall.

The second-floor Banqueting Suite contained gaming areas, an Animeleague merchandise desk, and a rest area, offering attendees a space to relax and enjoy the convention.

On August 26, Inverness-raised performer Meowgical Rosie graced the stage and later shared her inspiration for entering her subgenre: “I discovered J-pop music and idol culture online. The cute outfits and upbeat songs made me incredibly happy, and I wanted to spread that joy.”

When asked about her stage name, she explained, “I’ve always loved cats, so I wanted to include that. The term 'meowgical' captures the joyful, magical feeling I get from J-pop, combined with my name, Rosie.”

Rosie hopes to inspire others to follow their dreams despite facing ridicule. She affirmed, “I want people to feel confident in their passions and to pursue happiness without fear of judgment.”

This was not her first time at Animeleague Birmingham; she expressed excitement in returning to perform for an energetic crowd, connecting with fans both old and new.

On the second day, at 12:00 PM BST (11:00 AM UTC), J-pop idol LELE took the stage. With a background in a musically-oriented family, she credited anime opening theme songs for her inspiration to start singing in Japanese. “I create an anime in my mind for each song I write,” she revealed. LELE shared her pride for her latest release, “Hello Goodbye,” and looks forward to performing more shows both in the UK and internationally.

Meanwhile, at 12:32 PM BST (11:32 AM UTC), an anime opening quiz began, engaging attendees in guessing the anime from audio clips with vocal participation from the audience.

At 1:15 PM BST (12:15 PM UTC), a Q&A session commenced featuring actor D.C. Douglas. Initially, voice actor Elsie Lovelock was supposed to join but was unable to attend due to personal commitments. When asked about his favorite line from a project, Douglas delightfully recalled a humorous moment, alluding to a playful twist in his character's obsession with hands.

Performer Mi Yo Ri took the stage at 3:30 PM BST (2:30 PM UTC) on August 27, making her first appearance outside of Bristol. Despite recent injuries affecting her preparation, she expressed excitement for the performance and confirmed her eagerness to return.

On August 26, Cardiff-based Nattoheads and rapper Shao Dow were set to perform on the main stage, alongside panels discussing various topics related to anime and gaming, while the history of video gaming celebrated fan culture.

The schedule continued on August 27 with performances from Japanese artists MION and Crae Wolf, along with a talent show and interactive panel games that added to the convention’s vibrant atmosphere. Attendees also enjoyed screenings of popular anime series throughout both days, solidifying the event as a celebratory gathering for fans of all ages.
question:
What event took place in Birmingham, United Kingdom, attracting over 4,000 attendees in late August?  
A) Birmingham Anime & Gaming Con  
B) Birmingham Music Festival  
C) Birmingham Comic Con  
D) Birmingham Film Festival

title: Estonian parliament passes legalization of same-sex marriage
content:
On Tuesday, Estonia's parliament voted 55-34 to amend its Family Law Act, allowing same-sex marriages to take effect starting January 1. If approved by the president, Estonia would become the first former Soviet nation to legalize same-sex marriage.

Since the implementation of the Registered Partnership Act in 2016, same-sex couples have had the option to enter civil partnerships. However, these partnerships have not offered the same protections or adoption rights as marriage, allowing civil partners to adopt only if one is already a registered parent of the child.

Prime Minister [Name] expressed pride in the decision, stating, "I'm proud of my country. We're building a society where everyone's rights are respected and people can love freely." She emphasized that everyone should have the right to marry the person they love. "With this decision, we are finally standing alongside other Nordic countries and democratic nations around the world that have embraced marriage equality. This decision does not take anything away from anyone; rather, it provides something significant to many. It also reflects our society's commitment to care and respect for each other. I am proud of Estonia," she added.

A 2012 poll by the Estonian Human Rights Centre revealed that only 34% of the population supported same-sex marriage, but a recent survey in April indicated that support had risen to 53%.
question:
What significant legislative change did Estonia's parliament vote on Tuesday regarding same-sex marriage?

A) To allow civil partnerships for same-sex couples  
B) To amend the Family Law Act to permit same-sex marriages starting January 1  
C) To prohibit adoption rights for same-sex couples  
D) To repeal the Registered Partnership Act

title: Wikinews attends US debut of film The People's Joker
content:
On July 15, Wikinews covered the US premiere and second public screening of "The People's Joker," an unauthorized film adaptation of a comic book villain reimagined as a coming-of-age comedy. The event took place at the LGBT film festival in Los Angeles, with filmmakers Drew (director) and Bri LeRose in attendance.

This marks director Drew's first feature film, although she has previously worked as an editor and in various roles on numerous television productions.

Drew described "The People's Joker" as largely autobiographical, as she plays the main character who aspires to break into comedy. The character experiences similar struggles to Drew, eventually adopting the persona of "Joker the Harlequin," both a comic and a villain.

Co-writers Drew and LeRose participated in a Q&A session, addressing questions from a moderator and the audience. While both expressed fondness for the original comic series, they also offered critiques; Drew referred to it as "part of the problem." She praised actor and puppeteer featured in the film, calling him a "great collaborator" who provided valuable insights during production.

The rest of the cast chose not to appear on stage in solidarity with an unspecified situation.

Drew completed final edits to "The People's Joker" mere minutes before catching a flight for its world premiere at the 2022 Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF). Following that screening, she received a letter from the rights holders, which did not include demands but cautioned that "copyright law prohibits appropriating the character and universe as the vehicle for" her autobiographical narrative. The film had several private screenings afterward.

Drew mentioned that her team is currently developing a distribution strategy for "The People's Joker."

During the COVID-19 pandemic, LeRose commissioned Drew to re-edit the film into a comedy for just US$12. This collaboration eventually led to a version that incorporated all previous portrayals of the character in film. The two worked together to shape a script that fictionalized Drew's life, culminating in "The People's Joker."

The Outfest film festival ran from July 13 to July 16.
question:
What is the title of the unauthorized film adaptation that had its US general debut on July 15 at an LGBT film festival in Los Angeles?  

A) The People's Joker  
B) Joker's Journey  
C) Harlequin Dreams  
D) Comedy of Errors

title: Russian government: Mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin recorded on plane that crashed without survivors
content:
Yevgeny Prigozhin, 62, the Russian businessman and head of the Wagner Group private military company, was reportedly among the ten passengers on a plane that crashed on Wednesday, as confirmed by Russian authorities. The incident, which occurred without survivors, follows the Wagner Group's brief clashes with government forces and their advance on Moscow in June.

The Grey Zone, a Telegram account that supports Wagner, claimed—without providing evidence—that the plane was "shot down by an asset under the control of the Russian Ministry of Defense." They noted that Wednesday marked exactly two months since the group's "march of justice."

The aircraft, identified as RA-02795, was on a flight from Moscow to Saint Petersburg and had been sanctioned by the United States in 2019 due to its connections with Prigozhin. Early flight data indicated that about thirty minutes into the journey, the plane began to lose altitude rapidly, descending at nearly 8,000 feet per minute before losing altitude reports.

The Federal Air Transport Agency announced that an investigation is underway and confirmed other individuals aboard the flight, including Sergey Propustin, Evgeniy Makaryan, Aleksandr Totmin, and Valeriy Chekalov. Additionally, military intelligence agent Nikolay Matuseev was also aboard, along with crew members Commander Aleksei Levshin, copilot Rustam Karimov, and flight attendant Kristina Raspopova.

A Russian government spokesperson stated that there was no government involvement in the crash, characterizing speculation about the incident as unfounded and suggesting that Western narratives were misleading. "There are not many facts available yet, and these are still under investigation," the spokesperson said.

President Vladimir Putin expressed his condolences to the families of the victims, calling Prigozhin a "talented businessman" and reflecting on their first meeting in the early 1990s. "He had a difficult fate and made serious mistakes, but he achieved significant results," Putin said.

According to a U.S. official speaking to ABC News, initial assessments suggest that an explosion, possibly from a bomb, led to the crash, while another official favored the theory of a bomb as the cause. Brigadier General of the U.S. military remarked that their intelligence indicated Prigozhin was "likely killed" in the crash but did not provide evidence of foul play. 

President Joe Biden, on vacation nearby, stated he was not surprised by the incident, remarking, "There's not much that happens in Russia that Putin's not behind, but I don't know enough to provide an answer."

An advisor to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy asserted that the elimination of Prigozhin sends a clear signal from Putin to Russia's elite as the country approaches the 2024 elections.

Yevgeny Prigozhin, known as "Putin's chef," was born in 1961 in Leningrad (now Saint Petersburg). He began a twelve-year sentence for robbery and fraud in 1981 but was released in 1990. Initially, he started a hot dog business that garnered government contracts for food provision to schools and military entities.

In 2018, Prigozhin faced a U.S. indictment for his alleged financial support of the Internet Research Agency, which was accused of meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. He claimed to have founded Wagner in 2014, a group that played a significant role in conflicts in Ukraine and several African nations.

By late March 2022, estimates indicated that Wagner had approximately 1,000 fighters in Ukraine, which grew to around 50,000 by December, primarily composed of recruited prisoners. Prigozhin was known for his public criticisms of the Russian military, demanding resources for his fighters, and for orchestrating a mutiny in June that saw Wagner forces advance towards Moscow before turning back.

After the failed mutiny, he announced his intent to continue fighting alongside Russian forces, stating on social media, "I think we have achieved a lot... You will see our next victories at the front." His first video since the rebellion was reported to be released on Monday.
question:
What was the speculated cause of the plane crash that resulted in the death of Yevgeny Prigozhin and nine others? 

A) Mechanical failure  
B) Pilot error
